ARTICLE V
Reprisals by Landlords
[Ord. No. 86-35, § 7]
§ 16-56. Legislative Findings; Purpose of Article. [3-1-1973, § 1;
Ord. No. 81-23, § 1; Ord. No. 83-17, § 6; Ord. 86-35, § 8]
The mayor and council find that, although revised statutes, section N.J.S.A.
2A:42-10.10, et seq., prohibits landlords from taking reprisal for certain
activities of tenants, such prohibition can be enforced only in civil
proceedings in tribunals outside the borough; that the rights and remedies
thus provided to tenants frequently go unvindicated because of ignorance,
inconvenience, or expense; and that the objectives of the anti-reprisal law
will be furthered in the borough if violations thereof are deterred by threat
of prosecution and penalty in the municipal court. It is, therefore, the
purpose of this article, in the exercise of the police power and for the public
health, safety and general welfare, to prohibit reprisals by landlords for
certain activities of tenants and to provide penalties hereof.
§ 16-57. Applicability of Article to Rental Premises Used for
Dwelling. [3-13-1973, § 2; Ord. No. 81-23, § 1; Ord. 86-35, § 8]
This article shall apply to all rental premises or units used for dwelling
purposes in the borough except those exempted by section 16-39.
§ 16-58. Acts of Reprisal Prohibited. [3-13-1973, § 3; 7-31-1973, § 1;
Ord. No. 81-23, § 1]
No landlord of premises or units to which this article is applicable shall
serve a notice to quit upon any tenant or institute any action against a
tenant to recover possession of premises, whether by summary dispossess
proceedings, civil action for the possession of the land or otherwise:
(a) As a reprisal for the tenant's efforts to secure or enforce any rights
under the lease or contract, or under the laws or ordinances of the state
or of its governmental subdivisions, including the borough, or of the
United States;
(b) As a reprisal for the tenant's good faith complaint to a governmental
authority of the landlord's alleged violation of any health or safety law,
regulation, code or ordinance, or state law or regulation which has as
its objectives the regulation of premises used for dwelling purposes;
(c) As a reprisal for a tenant's being an organizer of, or a member of or
involved in any activities of any lawful tenant's organization;
(d) On account of the tenant's refusal or failure to comply with the terms of
the tenancy as altered by the landlord, if the landlord shall have altered
substantially the terms of the tenancy as a reprisal for any actions of the
tenant set forth in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section.
§ 16-56 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-58
BAO:223
§ 16-59. Rebuttable Presumption of Reprisal. [3-13-1973, § 4; Ord.
No. 81-23, § 1]
In the prosecution of any complaint under this article, the receipt by the
tenant of a notice to quit or any substantial alteration of the terms of the
tenancy without cause after:
§ 16-60. Compensation for Reprisal Rent Increases. [Ord. No.
83-17, § 7; Ord. No. 86-35, § 9]
The rent registration board shall have the power to determine whether or
not any rent being charged for a dwelling unit has been charged in violation
of this article. The board shall order a repaying of any such unlawful rent
for the period it was in effect or for a period of six months, whichever
is less. The board, in its discretion, may order either full repaying by the
landlord to the tenant of any unlawful rent which was so charged, or it may
order the landlord to credit the tenant the same amount which shall be
applied to future rent payments of the tenant. No additional rent increase
will be allowed for a period of one year after the landlord complies with the
repayment or credit provisions of this section and otherwise complies with
the provisions of this article.
Additionally, any tenant may pursue any action in the borough municipal
court for a violation of this article or any civil remedy provided by state law.
§ 16-61. (Reserved) [Reserved by Ord. No. 81-23]
Substantial alteration shall include the refusal to renew a lease or to
continue a tenancy of the tenant without cause.
Under subsection (b) of this section, the tenant shall first bring his good
faith complaint to the attention of the landlord or his agent and give the
landlord a reasonable time to correct the violation before complaining
to a governmental authority.
(a) The tenant attempts to secure or enforce any rights under the lease or
contract or under the laws of the state or of the United States; or
(b) The tenant, having brought a good faith complaint to the attention of
the landlord and having given him a reasonable time to correct the
alleged violation, complains to a governmental authority with a report
of the landlord's alleged violation of any health or safety law, regulation,
code or ordinance; or
(c) The tenant organizes, becomes a member of or becomes involved in any
activities of any lawful tenant's organization;
Shall create a rebuttable presumption that such notice or alteration
is a reprisal against the tenant for making such an attempt, report or
complaint, or for being an organizer of, a member of, or involved in any
activities of any lawful tenant's organization.
§ 16-58 PRINCETON CODE § 16-61
BAO:224
ARTICLE VI
Notice of Violation
§ 16-62. Notice of Violation Posting for any Public Health or
Emergency Condition. [Ord. No. 2010-07, § I]
In the event any agency of the Borough of Princeton shall issue a notice of
violation for any public health or emergency condition in respect to any real
property rented in the borough, for residential purpose, the agent of the
borough issuing said notice of violation may cause the notice of violation to
be posted on all doorways accessible from the street of the real property in
respect to which the notice of violation was issued where the agent of the
borough determines that the nature of the violation is such that notice is
required to protect the health and safety of the occupants of the property.
The owner of the property shall cause such notice of violation to remain so
posted, until the agency of the borough that issued the notice of violation
has declared the condition abated that caused the notice of violation to be
issued.
§ 16-62 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-62
BAO:225

ARTICLE VIII
Trust Fund for Affordable Housing
§ 16-69. Definitions. [Ord. No. 85-40, § 1]
AFFORDABLE HOUSING — Any housing unit with an acquisition price or
rent level not exceeding the maximum resale or rent level affordable by low
or moderate-income households pursuant to guidelines of the United States
Department of Housing and Urban Development or successor agency,
except the term shall include also any housing development in which at
least 50% of the housing units comply with the aforesaid standard and
a substantial portion of the remaining units have acquisition prices and
rent levels affordable by households of modest income, albeit in excess of
the aforesaid income limits, giving preference to the volunteers and public
employees who serve the borough and its schools and various agencies and
commissions.
§ 16-70. Findings and Purpose. [Ord. No. 85-40, § 1]
Mayor and council find and declare that the creation and preservation
of sound affordable housing in the borough serves the public interest.
Maintaining and improving a stock of sound affordable housing requires
affirmative steps by local government working cooperatively with public
bodies at all levels and with the private sector. The purpose of this article
is to create in the borough a trust fund to assist in the marshaling of public
and private monies dedicated to affordable housing projects and programs.
§ 16-71. Establishment of Trust Fund for Affordable Housing. [Ord.
No. 85-40, § 1]
There is hereby established a trust fund to be held and administered by the
borough for the creation and preservation of affordable housing within the
municipality. All monies contributed to this trust fund shall be administered
by mayor and council in such manner as it determines best serves the
purposes of the fund.
§ 16-72. Contributions to Trust Fund. [Ord. No. 85-40, § 1]
Any person may contribute monies to the trust fund established pursuant to
this article. Borough revenues may be contributed to the fund at such times
and in such amounts as mayor and council may determine from time to time.
§ 16-73. Administration of Trust Fund. [Ord. No. 85-40, § 1]
Mayor and council shall adopt a plan for the creation and preservation
of affordable housing in the borough. Thereafter, pursuant to such plan,
mayor and council may authorize such disbursements from the fund as it
deems necessary to facilitate implementation of the plan consistent with
the purposes of the fund. Activities which may be financed by such
disbursements shall include but need not be limited to acquisition of
property by the borough, direct subsidization of purchasers and renters on
§ 16-69 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-73
BAO:229
terms, and construction and rehabilitation projects and the administration
of same.
§ 16-73 PRINCETON CODE § 16-73
BAO:230
ARTICLE IX
Affordable Housing Board
§ 16-74. Purpose. [Ord. No. 87-21, § 1]
The purpose of this article is to create the Affordable Housing Board of the
Borough of Princeton to monitor the compliance of the borough in providing
housing for low and moderate income families under its Mt. Laurel II
obligation.
§ 16-75. Membership: Terms of office. [Ord. No. 87-21, § 1; Ord. No.
90-30, § I]
(a) The affordable housing board (hereinafter referred to as "board") shall
consist of seven voting members, all of whom shall be appointed by the
mayor with the advice and consent of council, providing, however, that:
(1) At least two of the members shall be residents of the
neighborhoods within which the housing units are situated.
(2) At least two of the members shall be from among minority racial or
ethnic groups (i.e. black, American Indian or Alaskan native,
Hispanic, or Asian or Pacific Islander) as defined in the Affirmative
Fair Housing Marketing Procedures of the New Jersey Housing and
Mortgage Finance Agency.
In addition, two members of the Princeton Borough Council shall
be council Liaison members and shall have no voting rights. The
Mayor of Princeton Borough and the housing coordinator shall be
ex-officio members of the board with no voting rights.
(b) Attendance by four voting members shall constitute a quorum.
(c) The initial term of office of the board members shall be three members
for the period ending December 31, 1987, two members for the period
ending December 31, 1988 and two members for the period ending
December 31, 1989. The terms of office shall thereafter be three years
or until their successors are appointed.
(d) The board shall elect a chairperson and a vicechairperson from among
its members. Their terms of office shall be one year and they shall be
eligible for reelection. The board may also elect a secretary, who need
not be a member of the board.
(e) Expenses of and reimbursements for the board will be included in
appropriations made for the housing department of the borough. The
borough council may employ or assign at the request of the board such
personnel or experts and other staff as the board deems necessary,
provided such obligations do not exceed the borough budgetary
allocation available to the board for such use.
§ 16-74 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-76
BAO:231
§ 16-76. Vacancies: Removal for Cause. [Ord. No. 87-21, § 1]
Any voting member of the board who has been absent without excuse from
three successive regular meetings shall be removed from office by the
mayor after notice and an opportunity to explain the absences.
§ 16-77. Powers. [Ord. No. 87-21, § 1]
The board is hereby granted and shall have and exercise the following
powers:
(a) Review with the assistance of the housing coordinator regulations
pertaining to the sale, rental, resale and re-renting of affordable
housing units.
(b) With the assistance of the housing coordinator prepare
recommendations for amendments and additions to regulations as it
deems necessary or appropriate to implement the purpose of the
affordable housing program.
(c) Establish deadlines for receipt of applications for certification to the
affordable housing program.
(d) Issue certifications of individuals to the affordable housing program,
determine the period of validity for such certifications, renew
certifications, revise certifications, or revoke certifications in
accordance with applicable rules and regulations.
(e) Establish priority and waiting lists of potential participants in the
affordable housing program in accordance with applicable rules and
regulations.
(f) Establish a selection process to choose among households of equal
priority ranking once they are placed in the appropriate pool of
potential participants in the affordable housing program and to rank
applicants not falling into a priority category.
(g) Hold hearings upon notice and adjudicate the complaints of applicants,
owners and renters if the applicant, owner or renter is not satisfied with
the rulings of the housing coordinator or the board. In matters involving
a hearing, the housing coordinator shall give 10 days' written notice to
all parties involved and shall give all interested parties an opportunity
to be heard.
(h) With the assistance of the housing coordinator make recommendations
to the borough council regarding how borough funds or funds collected
from developers for affordable housing should be spent and proposed
priorities for such expenditures.
(i) Review all housing marketing programs for all housing in the affordable
housing program.
§ 16-76 PRINCETON CODE § 16-77
BAO:232
(j) Monitor the continued existence of low and moderately priced dwelling
units as such by: reviewing the qualification of prospective purchasers
and tenants to confirm that they are eligible for the affordable housing
program; determining the maximum resale and rent levels of the low,
and moderately priced dwelling units to assure that the units remain
affordable to families of low or moderate income; and requiring that a
covenant be recorded with each deed restricting the resale to families
of low or moderate income, as appropriate.
(k) Provide annual reports of all activity to the borough, courts, federal,
state and local agencies as required.
(l) Review and restrict the installation of improvements or amenities
within or as part of low or moderately priced dwelling units which
would unduly increase the resale price and rentals of such units above
the amounts considered by the board affordable by families of low or
moderate income, and to control the low or moderately priced dwelling
unit resale price adjustments for homeowner installed improvements.
§ 16-77 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-77
BAO:233

ARTICLE X
Low and Moderate Income Housing Regulations6
§ 16-78. Purpose. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I]
The purpose of this chapter is to provide an administrative mechanism for
assuring the affordability of low and moderate income units developed in
the borough.
§ 16-79. Definitions. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 91-32, § 1]
The following words used in this article are intended to have the same
meaning as given to them by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the Mount
Laurel II decision and as clarified or otherwise modified by subsequent
decisions, if any, by a court of competent jurisdiction and by the New Jersey
Council on Affordable Housing in N.J.A.C. 5:92-1.3.
AFFORDABLE — A sales price or rent within the means of a low or
moderate income household as defined in N.J.A.C. 5:93-12.
BOARD — The Princeton Borough Affordable Housing Board.
COUNCIL OR COAH — The New Jersey Council on Affordable Housing
established under the New Jersey Fair Housing Act and which has primary
jurisdiction for the administration of housing obligations in accordance with
sound regional planning considerations in this state.
EXEMPT SALES — Includes the transfer of ownership between husband
and wife; the transfer of ownership between former spouses ordered as a
result of a judicial decree of divorce or judicial separation (not including
sales to third parties); the transfer of ownership between family members
as a result of inheritance; the transfer of ownership through an executor's
deed to any person; and the transfer of ownership by court order.
FAIR MARKET VALUE — The unrestricted price of a low or moderate
income housing unit if sold at a current real estate market rate.
INCLUSIONARY DEVELOPMENT — A residential housing development in
which a substantial percentage of the housing units is provided for a
reasonable range of low and moderate income households.
LOW INCOME HOUSING — Housing affordable according to Federal
Department of Housing and Urban Development or other recognized
standards for home ownership and rental costs, and occupied or reserved
for occupancy by households with a gross household income equal to 50%
or less of the median gross household income for households of the same
size within the housing region in which the housing is located, and which is
subject to affordability controls.
6. Editor's Note: This article shall take effect immediately upon passage, publication
according to law, filing with the Mercer County Planning Board, and upon the court's or
court master's approval in connection with litigation entitled Witherspoon Jackson
Development Corp. v. Borough of Princeton, Docket No. L-37675-84.
§ 16-78 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-79
BAO:235
MIDDLE INCOME HOUSING — Housing affordable according to Federal
Department of Housing and Urban Development or other recognized
standards for home ownership and rental costs and occupied or reserved for
occupancy by households with a gross household income equal to or more
than 80% but less than 150% of the median gross household income for
households of the same size within the housing region in which the housing
is located and which is subject to affordability controls.
MODERATE INCOME HOUSING — Housing affordable according to
Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development or other
recognized standards for home ownership and rental costs, and occupied
or reserved for occupancy by households with a gross household income
equal to or more than 50% but less than 80% of the median gross household
income for households of the same size within the housing region in which
the housing is located, and which is subject to affordability controls.
PRICE DIFFERENTIAL — The difference between the controlled unit sales
price and the fair market value as determined at the date of the proposed
contract of sale, after reasonable real estate broker fees have been paid.
REPAYMENT CLAUSE — The obligation of a seller exercising a repayment
option to pay 95% of the price differential to a municipality at closing for
use in the municipal housing plan.
REPAYMENT OPTION — The option of a seller of a low or moderate income
unit to sell a unit pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:92-12.7 at fair market value subject
to compliance with the terms of a repayment clause.
SET-ASIDE — The percentage of housing units devoted to low and moderate
income households within an inclusionary development.
§ 16-80. Resolution of Conflicting Provisions. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I]
Notwithstanding the provisions of any other ordinance to the contrary, the
provisions of this article shall apply to developments containing affordable
housing units.
§ 16-81. Determination of Affordability of Housing Units. [Ord. No.
90-33, § I; Ord. No. 91-32, § 2; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
(a) The affordability of a low, moderate or middle income unit shall be a
function of the rent or sales price which shall be established so as to
ensure that occupants do not pay a sum for shelter costs which exceeds
30% of gross annual income for rental units or 28% of gross annual
income for sales units in accordance with council on affordable housing
regulations as follows:
(1) Shelter costs for rental units shall include gross rent, including
utilities;
(2) Shelter costs for sales units shall include monthly principal,
interest, property taxes, condominium fees, homeowner and
private mortgage insurance;
§ 16-79 PRINCETON CODE § 16-81
BAO:236
(3) Sales costs of a unit shall be based on a presumed 5% down
payment;
(b) Rental and sales costs shall be fixed for a unit depending on bedroom
number calculated on the following basis as to household size:
(1) Efficiency units: one person households.
(2) One bedroom units: 1.5 person households.
(3) Two bedroom units: three person households.
(4) Three bedroom units: 4.5 person households.
(c) In the case of owner occupied housing rehabilitation assistance,
affordability shall be based on unit occupancy.
(d) In order to assure that low and moderate income units are affordable by
households whose income is less than the low and moderate income
ceilings the maximum sales price that may be offered for each such unit
shall on average be affordable to households earning at 57.5% of
median income for the housing region, and shall provide, as nearly as
practicable, for the following distribution of prices for every 20 low and
moderate income units:
Low income 1 at 40.0 through 42.5%
3 at 42.6 through 47.5%
6 at 47.6 through 50.0%
Moderate income 1 at 50.1 through 57.5%
1 at 57.6 through 64.5%
1 at 64.6 through 68.5%
1 at 68.6 through 72.5%
2 at 72.6 through 77.5%
4 at 77.6 through 80.0%
(e) For initial occupancy, priority shall be given to households that fall
within the median income categories delineated in subsection (d)
above.
(f) For initial occupancy or resale, to the greatest extent possible, certified
households shall be referred to available units for low, moderate and
middle income housing on the basis of two persons per bedroom. In no
case shall a household be referred to a unit that provides for more than
one extra bedroom per household.
(g) Master deeds of inclusionary developments must regulate
condominium or homeowner association fees or special assessments of
low and moderate income purchasers at a specific percentage of those
paid by market purchasers. The percentage that shall be paid by low
§ 16-81 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-81
BAO:237
§ 16-82. Certified Households; Distribution of Low and Moderate
Income Units and Bedroom Distribution. [Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
and moderate income purchasers shall be at least 1/3 of the
condominium or homeowner association fees paid by market
purchasers. Once established within the master deed, the percentage
may not be amended without prior approval from the council on
affordable housing.
(a) Households whose total gross annual income is measured at 50% or
below 50% of the authorized median income guidelines shall be
certified as low income households by the board and referred to units
designated for low income households. Households whose total gross
annual income is measured above 50% but below 80% of the authorized
median income shall be certified by the board as moderate income
households and referred to units designated for moderate income
households. The board shall issue to a low income or moderate income
household said written certification that shall remain valid for not more
than 120 days during which time said household shall enter into a valid
sales contract or lease for the affordable unit to which the household
has been referred by the board. Certification may be renewed in writing
at the request of a certified household no more than an additional
period of 120 days at the discretion of the board.
(b) Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.A.C. 5:93-7.2, at least half of all units
within each inclusionary development shall be affordable to low income
households.
(c) Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.A.C. 5:93-7.2 and 7.3, at least 1/3 of all
units in each bedroom distribution in an inclusionary development shall
be affordable to low income households.
(d) For inclusionary developments of low and moderate income units that
are not restricted to senior citizens, the bedroom distribution shall be
structured as follows:
(1) The combination of efficiency and one bedroom units shall be at
least 10% and no greater than 20% of the total low and moderate
income units;
(2) At least 30% of all low and moderate income units shall be two
bedroom units and at least 20% of all low and moderate income
units shall be three bedroom units. Low and moderate income units
restricted to senior citizens may utilize a modified bedroom
distribution. At a minimum the number of bedrooms shall equal the
number of senior citizen low and moderate income units within the
inclusionary development.
(e) Units constructed by the Borough of Princeton may also utilize a
modified bedroom distribution in order to provide greater flexibility in
construction.
§ 16-81 PRINCETON CODE § 16-83
BAO:238
§ 16-83. Controls on Affordability. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No.
96-14, § I]
(a) The developers of low and moderate income housing units shall
incorporate deed restrictions on all dwelling units sold or leased as
units affordable to low and moderate income households pursuant to
N.J.A.C. 5:92-5:93-9.1, et seq., the Council on Affordable Housing
Substantive Rules. Affordability controls shall remain in force as set
forth below.
(1) For owner-occupied rehabilitation as well as rental rehabilitation
renovated pursuant to the Princeton Borough Rehabilitation
Program, the controls shall be based upon a sliding scale
commensurate with the amount of funding needed to rehabilitate
the housing. The affordability controls for owner occupied
rehabilitation shall be as follows:
Amount of Funding Length of Controls
Up to $8,000 10 years
$8,001 to $12,000 14 years
$12,001 to $15,000 17 years
$15,001 or more 17 years + 1 year for every
$1,000 (or fraction) in funding
above $15,001
(2) The affordability controls for rental housing rehabilitation shall be:
Amount of Funding per unit Length of Controls
Up to $8,000 15 years
$8,001 to $12,000 19 years
$12,001 to $15,000 22 years
$15,001 or more 22 years + 1 year for every
$1,000 (or fraction) in funding
above $15,001
(3) The affordability controls for sale units, new affordable rental units
and rehabilitated rental units created pursuant to the affordable
housing overlay zones as set forth in this code shall be as follows:
Type of Housing Length of Controls
For Sale 40 years
Rental Housing 30 years
Rental Rehabilitation 20 years
§ 16-83 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-83
BAO:239
§ 16-84. General Provisions Concerning Uniform Deed Restrictive
Liens and Enforcement Through Certification of Occupancy or
Reoccupancy on Sale Units. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
(4) The affordability controls for new construction, affordable housing
shall vary, based upon whether the construction is publicly or
privately financed as set forth below:
Type of Housing Length of Controls
Publicly funded 99 years
Privately financed 30 years
(b) These affordability controls shall run with the land and shall place
limitations upon the re-sale/re-rental affordable units in accordance
with N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.1 et seq. and by means of any deed restrictions and/
or lien documents promulgated by the department of community
affairs, the Borough of Princeton and/or the council on affordable
housing. The time period of the control shall run from the date of the
initial deed of a particular unit to a qualified purchaser. In the case of a
rental unit, the affordability control shall begin to run from the issuance
of the initial certificate of occupancy of such low or moderate rental
unit.
(a) No certificate of occupancy for initial occupancy of a low or moderate
income sales unit shall issue unless there is a written determination by
the board that the unit is to be controlled by deed restriction and
mortgage lien as required herein and that said documents have been
recorded with the Mercer County Clerk and proof of such recording has
been provided to the borough clerk. The board shall make such
determination within 10 days of receipt of a proposed deed restriction
and mortgage lien. The deed restriction and mortgage lien required by
these regulations is appended to this section as Exhibit A and is
incorporated by reference herein.7
(b) No initial occupancy of a low or moderate income sales unit shall be
permitted prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy in accordance
with subsection (a) above.
(c) A certificate of reoccupancy for any occupancy of a low or moderate
income sales unit resulting from a resale shall be required and the
borough shall not issue such certificate unless there is a written
determination by the board that the unit is to be controlled by the deed
restriction and mortgage lien described herein and that said documents
have been recorded with the Mercer County Clerk and proof of such
recording has been provided to the borough clerk. The board shall
make such determination within 10 days of receipt of the proposed
deed restriction and mortgage lien.
7. Editor's Note: Exhibit A, referred to herein, may be found on file in the office of the
borough clerk attached to Ordinance No. 96-14.
§ 16-83 PRINCETON CODE § 16-84
BAO:240
§ 16-85. Option to Buy Sales Units. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No.
96-14, § I]
(d) The certificate of reoccupancy shall not be required in sales for which
controls are allowed to expire or in which the repayment option is being
exercised pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:92-12.2.
(e) No certificate of occupancy or reoccupancy shall be issued for a rental
unit(s), unless the deed restriction and mortgage lien required by this
ordinance is filed with the Clerk of Mercer County and proof of such
recording has been provided to the borough clerk. It shall be the
owner's obligation to file the deed restrictions with the Clerk of Mercer
County.
(f) The restrictive covenant, including the repayment clause, and the
mortgage lien shall have priority over all mortgages on the property
except for a first mortgage placed on the property by the mortgagee
prior to the expiration of resale controls.
(g) No unit (for sale or for rent) may be initially occupied or reoccupied by
any household, other than a household which has been certified as
income eligible for the unit size in accordance with COAH standards, by
the affordable housing board or the affordable housing management
service pursuant to an agreement between the borough and the service.
(a) The restrict covenant governing the deeds of low and moderate income
units shall include an option permitting purchase of the affordable
housing unit at the maximum allowable restricted sales price at the
time of the first nonexempt sale after controls on affordability have
been in effect on the unit for the period specified in this Borough Code.
The option to buy shall be first available to the Borough of Princeton,
then the department of community affairs, housing and mortgage
finance agency, or a qualified nonprofit agency as determined by COAH.
(b) All restrict covenants governing low and moderate income units shall
require the owner to notify the board and COAH by certified mail of any
intent to sell the unit at least 90 days prior to entering into an
agreement for the first nonexempt sale after controls have been in
effect on the housing unit for the period specified in this Borough Code.
(c) Upon receipt of such notice, the option to buy the unit at the maximum
allowable restricted sales price shall be available for 90 days. The
Board shall first notify the Borough of Princeton, then the department
of community affairs, housing and mortgage finance agency, and COAH
that the unit is for sale. If the Borough of Princeton exercises this
option, it may enter into a contract of sale. If the Borough of Princeton
fails to exercise this option within 90 days, the first of the other entities
giving notice to the seller of its intent to purchase during the ninety-day
period shall be entitled to purchase the unit. If the option to purchase
the unit at the maximum allowable restricted sales price is not
exercised by a written offer to purchase the housing unit within 90 days
§ 16-84 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-85
BAO:241
§ 16-86. Municipal Option. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
§ 16-87. State Option. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
of receipt of the intent to sell, the owner may proceed to sell the
housing unit. If the owner does not sell the unit within one year of the
date of the delivery of notice of intent to sell, the option to buy the
unit shall be restored and the owner shall be required to submit a new
notice of intent to sell at least 90 days prior to any future proposed date
of sale.
(d) Any option to buy a housing unit at the maximum allowable restricted
sales price shall be exercised by certified mail and shall be deemed
exercised upon mailing.
(a) The Borough of Princeton may elect to purchase a low or moderate
income unit provided for in N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.5 and may:
(1) Convey or rent the housing unit to a low or moderate income
purchaser or tenant at a price or rent not to exceed the maximum
allowable restricted sales price or rental for a period of time
established by the filing of the deed restriction.
(2) Convey the unit at fair market value subject to the provisions of the
following subsection (b).
(b) Upon purchase, the Borough of Princeton may maintain the unit as an
affordable housing unit or convey it at fair market value in accordance
with the following:
(1) Notify COAH of any proposed sale and sales price 90 days before
closing;
(2) Notify COAH of the price differential as defined in COAH
regulations;
(3) Deposit the price differential in the Borough of Princeton
Affordable Housing Trust Fund as set forth in section 15-5.18c and;
(4) Notify COAH by February 1 of each calendar year of the balance
within the affordable housing trust fund from such sale.
(c) Money deposited in the affordable housing trust fund from such sale
may not be expended until the Borough of Princeton submits and COAH
approves a repayment housing plan. COAH may approve the repayment
housing plan if it determines that it provides a realistic opportunity for
the creation, rehabilitation or maintenance of low and moderate income
housing.
(a) When the department of community affairs or housing and mortgage
finance agency elects to purchase a low or moderate income unit
pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.6, it may:
§ 16-85 PRINCETON CODE § 16-87
BAO:242
§ 16-88. Nonprofit Option. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
§ 16-89. Seller Option. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
(1) Convey or rent the housing unit to a low or moderate income
purchaser or tenant at a price or rent not to exceed the allowable
restricted sales price or rental; or
(2) Convey the unit at fair market value and utilize the price
differential to subsidize the construction, rehabilitation or
maintenance of low and moderate income housing within the
housing region.
(a) Nonprofit agencies may apply to COAH at any time for the right to
purchase low or moderate income units subsequent to the periods of
control for the types of housing specified in section 16-83.
(b) Nonprofit agencies that have been designated by COAH shall be eligible
to purchase low or moderate income units pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.7
for the sole purposes of conveying or renting the housing unit to a low
or moderate income purchaser or a tenant at a price or rent not to
exceed the allowable restricted sales price or rental. Low income units
shall be made available to low income purchasers or tenants and the
housing units shall be regulated by the restrictive covenant and lien
adopted by COAH.
(a) An eligible seller of a low or moderate income unit which has been
controlled for the period established herein, and who has provided
notice of an intent to sell may proceed with the sale if no eligible entity
as outlined in N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.8 and N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.4(c) and 9.7
exercises its option to purchase within 90 days.
(b) Subject to N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.8, the seller may elect to:
(1) Sell to a qualified low and moderate income household at the
controlled unit sales price in accordance with existing COAH
regulations, providing the unit is regulated by the restrictive
covenant and lien adopted by the borough or COAH for the
remainder of the original control period; or
(2) Exercise the repayment option and sell to any purchaser at market
price, providing that 95% of the price differential is paid to the
authority, as an instrument of the Borough of Princeton, at closing;
(c) If the sale will be to a qualified low or moderate income household, the
board shall certify the income qualifications of the purchaser and shall
ensure the housing unit is regulated by the restrictive covenant and lien
required by this Code.
(d) The board shall examine any contract of sale containing a repayment
option to determine if the proposed sales price bears a reasonable
relationship to the housing unit's fair market value. In making this
§ 16-87 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-89
BAO:243
§ 16-90. Borough Rejection of Repayment Option. [Ord. No. 90-33,
§ I; Ord. No. 96-14, § I]
determination, the board may rely on comparable sales data or an
appraisal. The board shall not approve any contract of sale where there
is a determination that the sales price does not bear a reasonable
relationship to fair market value. The board shall make a determination
within 20 days of receipt of the contract of sale and shall calculate the
repayment option payment.
(e) The board shall adopt an appeal procedure by which a seller may
submit written documentation requesting the board to (i) recompute
the repayment obligation if the seller believes an error has been made
or to (ii) reconsider a determination that a sales price does not bear a
reasonable relationship to fair market value. A repayment obligation
determination made as a result of an owner's appeal shall be a final
administrative determination of the board.
(f) The repayment shall occur at the date of closing and transfer of title for
the first nonexempt transaction after the expiration of controls on
affordability.
(g) Repayment proceeds shall be deposited in the Borough of Princeton's
Affordable Housing Trust Fund. Money deposited in the Borough of
Princeton's Affordable Housing Trust Fund from such sale may not be
expended until the Borough of Princeton submits and COAH approves a
repayment housing plan. COAH may approve the repayment housing
plan if it determines that it provides a realistic opportunity for the
creation, rehabilitation or maintenance of low and moderate income
housing.
(a) The Borough of Princeton shall have the right to determine that the
most desirable means of promoting an adequate supply of low and
moderate income housing is to prohibit the exercise of the payment
option and maintain controls on lower income housing units sold within
the borough beyond the period of affordability set forth in this Code.
Such determination shall be made by resolution of the mayor and
borough council and shall be effective upon filing with COAH and the
board. The resolution shall specify the time period for which the
payment option shall not be applicable. During such period, no seller in
the Borough of Princeton may utilize the repayment option permitted
by N.J.A.C. 5:93-9.9.
(b) If the borough exercises the option outlined in subsection (a), it shall:
(1) Provide public notice in a newspaper of general circulation; or
(2) Notify the board and COAH of the borough's action. The board shall
ensure that the deed restriction of all affected housing units reflect
the extended period of controls.

§ 16-91. Continued Application of Options to Create, Rehabilitate or
Maintain Low and Moderate Income Units. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I; Ord.

§ 16-92. Impact of Foreclosure on Resale While Controls are in

Pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:80-26.5(e), a judgment of foreclosure or deed in lieu
of foreclosure by a financial institution regulated by state and/or federal law
or by a lender on the secondary mortgage market (including but not limited
to the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Home Loan Mortgage
Corporation, the Government National Mortgage Association or an entity
acting on their behalf) shall not extinguish controls on affordable housing
units. All affordable restrictions imposed by the borough ordinance, the
New Jersey Council on Affordable Housing, and any recorded covenants
shall remain in effect despite entry and enforcement of any judgment of
foreclosure with respect to the affordable unit for the balance of the
intended period of controls.
§ 16-93. Excess Proceeds upon Foreclosure. [Ord. No. 90-33, § I]
§ 16-93A. Affordable Housing Rehabilitation Loan Program. [Ord.
No. 96-14, § I]
The purpose of the rehabilitation loan program is to rehabilitate
substandard housing units (units with health and safety code violations)
occupied by low or moderate income households by providing deferredpayment
loans to the property owners.
(a) When a housing unit has been maintained as low or moderate income
unit after controls have been in effect for the period specified herein,
the restrictive covenant governing the housing units shall allow the
Borough of Princeton, the state, nonprofit agencies and sellers of low
and moderate income units to again exercise all the same options as
provided in this section.
(a) In the event of a foreclosure sale, the owner of the affordable housing
unit shall be personally obligated to pay to the authority responsible for
assuring affordability, any surplus funds, but only to the extent that
such surplus funds exceed the difference between the maximum price
permitted at the time of foreclosure and the amount necessary to
redeem the debt to the financial institution including costs of
foreclosure.
(a) Eligibility for participation in program:
(1) In order to participate in the loan program, the property owner (in
the case of owner-occupied property) or tenant (in the case of
rental property) must be within the guidelines for qualification as a
low or moderate income family.
§ 16-91 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-93A
BAO:245
(2) Loans averaging at least $8,000 are available for the repair or
replacement of major systems which are in violation of the local
property maintenance code. Major systems include: roofs,
plumbing (including wells), heating, electricity, sanitary plumbing
and/or load bearing structural systems. Rehabilitation activity does
not include luxury improvements, the purchase of appliances (with
the exception of stoves), or improvements that are strictly
cosmetic.
(b) Administration of the program:
(1) The housing coordinator shall be the program administrator
appointed by the mayor and borough council and will administer
the program under the supervision of the Princeton Borough Non-
Profit Housing and Redevelopment Corporation.
(2) A marketing plan, subject to the approval of COAH or the New
Jersey Superior Court, will be prepared which includes a
combination of some, though not necessarily all, of the following:
brochures; posters; cable television and radio announcements;
notices in utility bills, municipal tax bills, municipal publication;
informational meetings with welfare organizations, urban action
community groups, personnel departments of local employers,
social workers, civic and religious leaders, senior citizens groups
and fraternal organizations.
(3) Files will be maintained on each program applicant which will
include: the name of each applicant; if disapproved, the reason for
disapproval; if approved: proof of income eligibility, initial
inspection by the building inspector, bids by contractors, work
contract (final version), progress reports, copy of final inspection
and the lien on the property.
(4) A rehabilitation manual that complies with COAH's rules will be
developed which summarizes the borough's rehabilitation
program. It will describe: the program's staff and their
responsibilities; procedures for program marketing; eligible
repairs and improvements; the amount of money available;
financing terms; income qualification criteria; intake application
procedures; review and work approval procedures; and length of
affordability controls.
(5) Annual monitoring reports will be sent to COAH as required by
N.J.A.C. 5:93-12.
(6) The borough is responsible for funding the program with a
minimum of $10,000 per unit to be broken down to $2,000 for
administrative costs and $8,000 for the rehabilitation activity.
Rehabilitation activity must average at least $8,000 per unit. An
amount sufficient to fund 1/3 of the rehabilitation component must
be provided in the first year and 1/6 in each subsequent year.
§ 16-93A PRINCETON CODE § 16-93A
BAO:246
§ 16-93B. Affordable Housing Down Payment Assistance Loan
Program. [Ord. No. 99-20, § I]
The purpose of the down payment assistance loan program is to provide
deferred-payment loans to income-eligible families to cover the down
payment amount and therefore make it possible for those families to
purchase low and moderate income affordable housing units in the borough.
(c) Conditions on receiving loans:
(1) The borough will place a lien on the property for the total cost of
the approved rehabilitation. Payment on the loan will be deferred
as long as the property owner maintains the property as his or her
principal residence. If the property owner remains at the property
for the full term of the loan, the full amount of the loan will be
"forgiven" and converted to a grant. If the property is sold prior to
the completion of the full term of the loan, the repayment of the
loan is for the principal amount plus interest (as stipulated in the
mortgage note) and must be paid from the sale proceeds.
(2) Monies from repaid loans, including principal plus interest, shall be
used to first rehabilitate other dwelling units which are eligible for
participation in this program. Once funding is made available for
additional rehabilitation, monies from repaid loans, including
principal and interest, shall be utilized for other low and moderate
income housing purposes, including, but not limited to, the
repayment of any municipal debt incurred in support of the
creation or maintenance of low and moderate income units, down
payment assistance or any other housing activity involving the
Princeton Borough Affordable Housing Program.
(3) The length of the term of the rental rehabilitation loan shall be
fixed in accordance with this chapter. Repayment terms of said
loans shall be established by the Princeton Borough Non-Profit
Housing and Redevelopment Corporation which shall be based
upon an evaluation of all circumstances surrounding the
rehabilitation loan request.
(4) Payments for rehabilitation work, execution of rehabilitation loan
agreements, etc. shall be in accordance with the rehabilitation
program procedures manual which is on file with the borough
clerk.
(a) Eligibility for participation in program:
(1) In order to participate in the loan program, the applicant must be
within the guidelines for qualification as a low or moderate income
family.
(2) The minimum amount of any loan shall be $8,500.
(b) Administration of the program:
§ 16-93A BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-93B
BAO:247
(1) Purchases seeking down payment assistance through this program
must make application to the Princeton Borough Affordable
Housing Board.
(2) Any approval by the housing board for down payment assistance
shall be subject to certification by the borough's chief financial
officer that funds for the loan are available for said assistance and
have been approved by the mayor and council.
(3) The program shall be funded through the Princeton Borough
Affordable Housing Program.
(c) Conditions on receiving loans:
(1) The purchaser must agree to execute a secured second mortgage
on the property if the down payment assistance loan is granted.
(2) The down payment assistance loan is a deferred payment loan, with
the loan amount and accrued interest to be repaid either upon the
sale of the unit or upon the expiration of 30 years from the date of
the execution of the second mortgage, whichever occurs first.
(3) The interest rate to be charged in connection with the down
payment assistance loan shall be at that rate which the borough
has most recently borrowed money for a capital project, which rate
shall be certified to the housing board by the borough's chief
financial officer from time to time.
§ 16-93B PRINCETON CODE § 16-93B
BAO:248
ARTICLE XI
Affordable Housing Utility
§ 16-94. Established: Purpose. [Ord. No. 90-8, §§ 1 — 8]
(a) Pursuant to the "Local Budget Law", N.J.S.A. 40A:4-1 et seq., an
affordable housing utility is established in the Borough of Princeton and
the same shall be known and cited as the "Borough of Princeton
Affordable Housing Utility".
(b) The affordable housing utility shall commence as of August 3, 1989 and
the same shall be retroactive to that date.
(c) The affordable housing utility budget shall set forth the appropriations
in the form and detail prescribed by the regulations of the local
governing body and may include:
(1) Operations;
(2) Interest and debt retirement, and
(3) Deferred charges and statutory expenditures.
(d) The borough officers and employees are directed and empowered to
adopt accounting procedures consistent with this article and the
aforesaid statutes in the creation of the affordable housing utility.
(e) The affordable housing utility shall be governed by the governing body
of the Borough of Princeton.
(f) All matters with respect to the operation and conduct of the affordable
housing utility not determined by this article shall be determined by
resolutions to be hereafter adopted.
(g) Upon completion of the affordable housing units and the appropriate
sale of those units, after all required debt service payments are made
this utility will terminate.
§ 16-94 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-94
BAO:249

ARTICLE XII
Municipal Housing Liaison
§ 16-95. Purpose. [Ord. No. 2007-16, § 1]
The purpose of this article is to create the administrative mechanisms
needed for the execution of the Borough of Princeton's responsibility to
assist in the provision of affordable housing pursuant to the Fair Housing
Act of 1985.
§ 16-96. Definitions. [Ord. No. 2007-16, § 2]
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings
indicated:
ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT — The entity responsible for administering the
affordability controls of some or all units in the affordable housing program
for the Borough of Princeton to ensure that the restricted units under
administration are affirmatively marketed and sold or rented, as applicable,
only to low- and moderate-income households.
MUNICIPAL HOUSING LIAISON — The employee charged by the governing
body with the responsibility for oversight and administration of the
affordable housing program for the Borough of Princeton.
§ 16-97. Establishment of Municipal Housing Liaison Position and
Compensation; Powers and Duties. [Ord. No. 2007-16, § 3]
(a) Establishment of position of municipal housing liaison. There is hereby
established the position of municipal housing liaison for the Borough of
Princeton.
(b) Subject to the approval of the Council on Affordable Housing (COAH),
the municipal housing liaison shall be appointed by the governing body
and may be a full or part time municipal employee.
(c) The municipal housing liaison shall be responsible for oversight and
administration of the affordable housing program for the Borough of
Princeton, including the following responsibilities which may not be
contracted out, exclusive of paragraph (6) which may be contracted
out:
(1) Serving as the Borough of Princeton's primary point of contact for
all inquiries from the state, affordable housing providers,
administrative agents, and interested households;
(2) Monitoring the status of all restricted units in the Borough of
Princeton's Fair Share Plan;
(3) Compiling, verifying, and submitting annual reports as required by
COAH;
§ 16-95 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-97
BAO:251
(4) Coordinating meetings with affordable housing providers and
administrative agents, as applicable;
(5) Attending continuing education opportunities on affordability
controls, compliance monitoring, and affirmative marketing as
offered or approved by COAH;
(6) If applicable, serving as the administrative agent for some or all of
the restricted units in the Borough of Princeton as described in
subsection (f) below.
(d) Subject to approval by COAH, the Borough of Princeton may contract
with or authorize a consultant, authority, government or any agency
charged by the governing body, which entity shall have the
responsibility of administering the affordable housing program of the
Borough of Princeton, except for those responsibilities which may not
be contracted out pursuant to subsection (c) above. If the Borough of
Princeton contracts with another entity to administer all or any part of
the affordable housing program, including the affordability controls and
Affirmative Marketing Plan, the municipal housing liaison shall
supervise the contracting administrative agent.
(e) Compensation. Compensation shall be fixed by the governing body at
the time of the appointment of the municipal housing liaison.
(f) Administrative powers and duties assigned to the municipal housing
liaison.
(1) Affirmative marketing.
a. Conducting an outreach process to insure affirmative
marketing of affordable housing units in accordance with the
Affirmative Marketing Plan of the Borough of Princeton and
the provisions of N.J.A.C. 5:80-26.15; and
b. Providing counseling or contracting to provide counseling
services to low and moderate income applicants on subjects
such as budgeting, credit issues, mortgage qualification, rental
lease requirements, and landlord/tenant law.
(2) Household certification.
a. Soliciting, scheduling, conducting and following up on
interviews with interested households;
b. Conducting interviews and obtaining sufficient documentation
of gross income and assets upon which to base a determination
of income eligibility for a low- or moderate-income unit;
c. Providing written notification to each applicant as to the
determination of eligibility or noneligibility;
§ 16-97 PRINCETON CODE § 16-97
BAO:252
d. Requiring that all certified applicants for restricted units
execute a certificate substantially in the form, as applicable, of
either the ownership or rental certificates set forth in
Appendices J and K of N.J.A.C. 5:80-26.1 et seq.;
e. Creating and maintaining a referral list of eligible applicant
households living in the housing region and eligible applicant
households with members working in the housing region
where the units are located; and
f. Employing the random selection process as provided in the
Affirmative Marketing Plan of the Borough of Princeton when
referring households for certification to affordable units.
(3) Affordability controls.
a. Furnishing to attorneys or closing agents forms of deed
restrictions and mortgages for recording at the time of
conveyance of title of each restricted unit;
b. Creating and maintaining a file on each restricted unit for its
control period, including the recorded deed with restrictions,
recorded mortgage and note, as appropriate;
c. Ensuring that the removal of the deed restrictions and
cancellation of the mortgage note are effectuated and properly
filed with the appropriate county's register of deeds or county
clerk's office after the termination of the affordability controls
for each restricted unit;
d. Communicating with lenders regarding foreclosures; and
e. Ensuring the issuance of continuing certificates of occupancy
or certifications pursuant to N.J.A.C. 5:80-26.10.
(4) Resale and rental.
a. Instituting and maintaining an effective means of
communicating information between owners and the
administrative agent regarding the availability of restricted
units for resale or rental; and
b. Instituting and maintaining an effective means of
communicating information to low- and moderate-income
households regarding the availability of restricted units for
resale or rerental.
(5) Processing request from unit owners.
a. Reviewing and approving requests from owners of restricted
units who wish to take out home equity loans or refinance
during the term of their ownership;
§ 16-97 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-97
BAO:253
b. Reviewing and approving requests to increase sales prices
from owners of restricted units who wish to make capital
improvements to the units that would affect the selling price,
such authorizations to be limited to those improvements
resulting in additional bedrooms or bathrooms and the cost of
central air conditioning systems; and
c. Processing requests and making determinations on requests
by owners of restricted units for hardship waivers.
(6) Enforcement.
a. Securing annually lists of all affordable housing units for which
tax bills are mailed to absentee owners and notifying all such
owners that they must either move back to their unit or sell it;
b. Securing from all developers and sponsors of restricted units,
at the earliest point of contact in the processing of the project
or development, written acknowledgement of the requirement
that no restricted unit can be offered, or in any other way
committed, to any person, other than a household duly
certified to the unit by the administrative agent;
c. The posting annually in all rental properties, including twofamily
homes, of a notice as to the maximum permitted rent
together with the telephone number of the administrative
agent where complaints of excess rent can be made;
d. Sending annual mailings to all owners of affordable dwelling
units, reminding them of the notices and requirements outlined
in N.J.A.C. 5:80-26.18(d)4;
e. Establishing a program for diverting unlawful rent payments to
the municipality's affordable housing trust fund or other
appropriate municipal fund approved by the DCA;
f. Creating and publishing a written operating manual, as
approved by COAH, setting forth procedures for administering
such affordability controls; and
g. Providing annual reports to COAH as required.
(7) The administrative agent shall have authority to take all actions
necessary and appropriate to carry out its responsibilities
hereunder.
§ 16-97 PRINCETON CODE § 16-97
BAO:254
Chapter B17
(RESERVED)
Chapter B17A
LAND USE AND ZONING
§ 16-97 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § 16-97
BAO:255

Division 1
Zoning In General
§ B17A-200. Purpose of chapter. [Ord. No. 77-1, § 2; Ord. No. 86-20,
§ 1.]
The purposes of this chapter shall be to promote and to protect the public
health, safety, comfort, convenience, prosperity, amenity and other aspects
of the general welfare, and in particular to do so by implementing the
following policies set forth in the master plan of the borough:
(a) To protect and preserve the character of the borough as primarily a
residential and college town and to provide for reasonable and
necessary adjustments to present day social and economic trends.
(b) To control the development of the borough's residential areas by
limiting the density of new development in such areas and by
preventing commercial and industrial uses.
(c) To encourage the development of a range of housing types at various
price levels, particularly around the center of the borough, with
emphasis upon dwelling units for single persons and small families, in
order to take into account the changing age structure of the borough's
population.
(d) To provide a buffer area devoted primarily to apartments and office
buildings between the business areas and nearby areas of low and
medium density residential development.
(e) To continue the present predominance of small retail and specialty
stores in the borough's business districts and to prevent therein:
(1) The development of large retail stores serving a regional marketing
area and generating heavy traffic which would overburden the
borough's street system, and
(2) The extension of the borough's commercial districts into adjacent
residential areas.
(f) To guide the further development of the downtown area in relation to
the capacity of the street system of that area, in order to prevent
additional traffic congestion.
(g) To provide appropriate small areas catering to neighborhood daily
shopping needs in other parts of the borough.
(h) To provide an appropriate area for automotive and other similar
services and to prevent the spreading of such services into the
remainder of the borough's business areas.
(i) To provide increased flexibility for the future growth of the educational
institutions which play so large a part in the borough's economy and
§ B17A-200 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § B17A-200
BAO:257
§ B17A-201. Definitions. [Ord. No. 2012-12 § 1; Ord. No. 77-1, § 2;
Ord. No. 78-26, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 80-24, § 1; Ord. No. 81-24, § 1; Ord.
No. 83-25, § 1; Ord. No. 83-38, § 3; Ord. No. 86-20, § 2; Ord. No.
89-26, § 1; Ord. No. 91-2, § 1; Ord. No. 94-19, § I; Ord. No. 95-20,
§ 1; Ord. No. 98-9, § I; Ord. No. 2000-8, § I; Ord. No. 2003-9, § IV;
Ord. No. 2003-29, § I; Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1;
Ord. No. 2009-01, § II; Ord. No. 2009-33, § I; Ord. No. 2014-44 § 5;
Ord. No. 2015-48 § 2; Ord. No. 2016-42 § 7; Ord. No. 2017-8 § 4;
Ord. No. 2017-52 § 2; Ord. No. 2018-24 §§ 2, 4, 5]
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words or phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.
Words used in the present tense include the future. The singular number
includes the plural and the plural the singular. The word "person" includes a
corporation as well as an individual. The word "lot" includes the word "plot."
"Building" includes any part thereof. The word "use" shall include the words
"or intended, arranged or designed to be occupied or used."
ACCESSORY BUILDING — See "building, accessory."
ACCESSORY USE, OR ACCESSORY — An "accessory use" is a use which is
clearly incidental to, customarily found in connection with and, except in
the case of parking spaces or loading berths, located on the same lot as the
principal use to which it is related. When "accessory" is used in the text,
it shall have the same meaning as "accessory use." "Accessory use" shall
include without limitation, the following:
ANTENNA — A system of electrical conductors that transmit or receive
radio frequency signals for wireless communications.
cultural life, while at the same time providing protection to residential
zones immediately adjacent to such institutions.
(j) To preserve and enhance the historic architecture of the community.
The council hereby finds that the adoption and implementation of the
policies set forth in this section is necessary in order to prevent the
overcrowding of land or buildings; to avoid undue concentration of
population and to lessen congestion in the streets; to provide adequate
light and air; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; and
to promote health and other aspects of the general welfare.
(a) Residential accommodations for servants.
(b) Accessory parking spaces, loading berths and signs.
(c) Home occupations.
(d) Rental of one or two rooms in a dwelling unit for residential purposes.
(e) Family day care.
§ B17A-200 PRINCETON CODE § B17A-201
BAO:258
ANTENNA SUPPORT STRUCTURE — A structure other than a
telecommunications tower which is attached to a building and on which one
or more antennas are located.
ASSISTED LIVING RESIDENCE — A facility which is licensed by the
department of health, in accordance with N.J.A.C. 8:36 as that section exists
as of March 14, 2000, to provide apartment-style housing and congregate
dining and to assure that assisted living services are available when needed.
An assisted living residence is within the continuum of senior housing types
recommended by the Princeton Community Master Plan. It is a form of
institutional health care facility which offers assisted living services for
the frail elderly and other persons with physical or cognitive impairment.
This does not include individuals requiring acute, intermediate, ongoing,
residential type supervised treatment for social, emotional, psychiatric,
addictions or school classified difficulties. It is an alternative for persons
who because of age, illness, or infirmity cannot live independently, but
who do not require continuous nursing home-level care. "Assisted living
services" means a coordinated array of supportive personal and health
services, available 24 hours per day, to residents who have been assessed to
need these services, including residents who require formal long-term care.
ATTIC — The part of a building that is immediately below and wholly or
partly within the roof framing.
BASEMENT — Space in which the ceiling (defined as the bottom of the
structural members of the floor above) is less than four feet above the
average finished grade line along the outside walls of the building and is
more than seven feet in height measured from the finished floor, except at
points of entry or access.
BILLBOARD — A sign which directs attention to a business, commodity,
service or entertainment conducted, sold or offered elsewhere than upon
the lot on which such sign is situated.
BUILDING OR STRUCTURE — Any combination of materials forming any
construction, except: (a) Where entirely underground, so as to permit the
use of the ground above the same as if no building were present and
without substantial change in the existing grade; and (b) fences and walls
of six feet in height or less. The terms "building" and "structure" are used
synonymously.
BUILDING, ACCESSORY — A detached building, subordinate to the
principal building on the same lot as the principal building and with no
cooking facilities, except outdoor barbecue pits or picnic fireplaces, or
sleeping facilities. The term "accessory building" shall not include
secondary residence buildings; garden or tool houses with an area of less
than 32 square feet and without a foundation when located in accordance
with section 17A-380 of this article, but it shall include the following:
Radio and television antennae, except for antennae installed on the roof
of a principal building and extending not more than 15 feet above the
highest level thereof.
(a)

BAO:259
BUILDING, PRINCIPAL — That building which houses the primary use on a
lot. In the R1, R2, R3 and R4 zoning districts, only one principal building is
permitted on a lot. The following shall be considered part of the principal
building:
BUILDING, SECONDARY RESIDENCE — A detached building that is
subordinate to the principal building on the same lot and that: (a) in part
is used for and includes one or more permitted principal or accessory uses;
and (b) in remaining part contains not more than one secondary residence.
COLLOCATION — Use of a common PWTF or a common site by two or more
wireless license holders or by one wireless license holder for more than
one type of communication technology and/or placement of a PWTF on a
structure.
CONTINUING CARE RETIREMENT COMMUNITY (CCRC) — A
development of residential living units exclusively for persons who are 62
years of age or older, or for couples, one of whom is at least 62 years of
age, which provides a continuum of accommodations and care and which
provides "continuing care" as an integral part of the residential
development. Continuing care is the provision of lodging and nursing,
medical or other health related services at the CCRC or at another location
to an individual pursuant to an agreement effective for the life of the
individual or for a period greater than one year, and, in consideration of the
payment of an entrance fee with or without other periodic charges, provided
that the person receiving the care is not related to the person who provides
the care.
The continuing care retirement community (CCRC) must include
independent living units and assisted living units and nursing care units.
Amateur radio receiving and transmitting towers of 15 feet or less in
height.

gain.

(e) Garden houses, tool houses, playhouses and greenhouses.
(f) Detached garages.
Any attached accessory building, including an attached garage or
attached roofed carport, including those carports attached only by a
roofed breezeway.
(a)
(b) A roofed porch attached to the principal building.
A secondary residence located within a one-family dwelling.

principal buildings.

§ B17A-201 PRINCETON CODE § B17A-201
BAO:260
The nursing care units and/or assisted living units may be made available
at the CCRC or by contract at another facility. The CCRC shall also include
facilities and arrangements for providing continuing care and meals for
residents, with or without common dining facilities, and may include
accessory services customarily incidental to a continuing care retirement
community.
The following accessory structures and uses shall be permitted in a
continuing care retirement community: recreation facilities, physical
therapy facilities, entertainment facilities, libraries, food preparation
facilities, dining facilities, linen service facilities, nursing services,
housekeeping services, security facilities, administrative offices, staff
facilities, storage and maintenance facilities, chapels, temporary guest
lodging facilities, barber shop and beauty parlors, facilities for the sale
of sundries, personal articles, newspapers, food, and similar convenience
products to the residents, and such other uses as are customarily associated
with and subordinate to the principal permitted uses. Except as may
otherwise be authorized, all accessory facilities, functions, and services
shall be for the use and benefit of the residents of the facility. The space for
accessory uses shall not constitute gross floor area for purposes of any floor
area ratio limitation to the extent of 5% of the total gross floor area of the
CCRC development, excluding the space for accessory uses.
COURT, INNER — An open space which is enclosed on all sides by exterior
walls of a building and is unobstructed from the ground to the sky.
COURT, OUTER — An open space which is enclosed on three sides by
exterior walls of a building and is unobstructed from the ground to the sky.
COVERAGE — The area covered by all buildings on a lot, expressed as a
percentage of the lot area.
CURB LEVEL — The average elevation, established by existing curbs or
borough ordinance of the street grade along the entire street line of the lot.
Where a building is on a corner lot, the curb level is the average level of
such elevations on the two intersecting streets. Where a front yard of 25
feet or more is provided or where there are two or more principal buildings
on the lot, the curb level is the average level of the land immediately
adjacent to the building prior to or after any excavation or fill, as may be
determined by the development enforcement officer.
DORMITORY — That part of an educational institution which provides
sleeping accommodations, with or without accessory common rooms and
cooking and eating facilities, for groups of unmarried students in
attendance at the educational institution.
DRIVE-IN/DRIVE-THROUGH — An establishment that by design, physical
facilities, service or packaging procedures encourages or permits
Court, depth of outer. The average distance from the unenclosed side of
the court to the farthest wall which is parallel to, or walls which make
an angle of less than 45° with, the unenclosed side.
(a)
(b) Court, width of outer. The length of the unenclosed side of the court.

BAO:261
customers to receive services or obtain goods while remaining in their
motor vehicles.
DWELLING UNIT — A building or entirely self-contained portion thereof,
containing complete housekeeping facilities for only one family, including
any domestic servants employed on the premises, and having no cooking,
food preparation or sanitary facilities in common with other dwelling units
and no common enclosed space, other than vestibules, entrance or porches,
and laundry, heating and air conditioning rooms and equipment. The terms
shall not include a boarding house, convalescent home, dormitory, fraternity
or sorority house, hotel, nursing or similar home or other similar building,
or a secondary residence.
DWELLING, ATTACHED — A one-family dwelling with two common or party
walls separating it from adjacent units on both sides, or one party wall in
the case of a building at the end of a group of attached dwellings.
DWELLING, MULTIPLE — A building or portion thereof containing three or
more dwelling units, other than attached dwellings.
DWELLING, ONE-FAMILY — A detached building containing one dwelling
unit only, or if permitted in the district, one dwelling unit and secondary
residence. The term shall include a parish house.
DWELLING, TWO-FAMILY — A detached building containing two dwelling
units, either side by side, as in the case of a semi-detached dwelling, or one
over the other.
EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION — An education institution of higher
learning chartered by the state, or a private educational institution
approved by and subject to regulations prescribed by the state and giving
instructions or affording facilities for study and research in academic or
technical subjects primarily at or above the college level.
ENLARGEMENT — An addition to the aggregate floor area or an increase in
the height of any existing building or area of the lot covered by any building.
EXTENSION — An increase in the amount of existing floor area used for an
existing use with an existing building.
FAMILY — One or more persons occupying one dwelling unit as a single,
non-profit housekeeping unit, whose relationship is of a stable and domestic
character. Uses such as non-familial institutional uses, rooming houses,
hotels, clubs, fraternities, sororities, transient housing or similar types of
housing shall not be considered family uses. It shall be considered a family
use to provide supportive personal and health services within a dwelling
unit to family members residing in the dwelling unit.
FAMILY DAY CARE — The provision of child care services for a fee, or
other consideration, to no more than five children, by a family occupying
a dwelling unit, provided that the use complies with the requirements of
section 17A-228(c)(2)e,f.
Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 30:5B-18, a child being cared for under the following
circumstances is not included in the number of children receiving child care
§ B17A-201 PRINCETON CODE § B17A-201
BAO:262
services, provided that there shall be no more than three such children
within either or both of the following categories:
FLOOR AREA — The total area of all of the stories of all structures on
the lot, measured from the outside faces of the exterior walls or from
the exterior roof edges where the structure has no walls and including
the following, although not by way of limitation: interior balconies and
mezzanines, roofed and/or enclosed areas such as sheds, barns, garages,
and carports.
Attic space in a single family or two family residence with a height of seven
feet or more measured from the finished floor to the roof rafter shall be
counted as floor area except for that area that is up to one-third of the
area of the floor directly below. Attic areas in a single family or two family
residence with a height of less than seven feet measured from finished floor
to roof rafter shall not be counted as floor area.
If an interior space in a one or two family structure has a ceiling height of
12 feet or greater, the floor area of that space shall be counted twice for the
purpose of floor area calculation. If an interior space in a one or two family
structure has a sloped ceiling, only that portion of the floor having a ceiling
height of 12 feet or greater shall be counted twice for the purpose of floor
area calculation.
For single- and two-family dwellings, the following shall be exempt from the
calculation of floor area (see Fig. 1):

A/C condenser units, generators, transformers, above-ground fuel tanks
and other similar devices, not to exceed 100 square feet in the aggregate.

floor area

platforms, up to 200 square feet. Any additional square footage beyond
the first 200 square feet shall be included in the calculation
(B) That portion of any garage, porte-cochere, carport or other accessory
structure that is located behind the rearmost wall of the dwelling (C),
provided that said structure is no greater than 1 story and 15 feet in
height to the peak of the roof, not to exceed 300 square feet
