§ T5AA-2 PRINCETON CODE § T5AA-5
BAO:826
nature of subscription fees paid by subscribers for cable television
reception service in the Municipality or any higher amount permitted by
the Act or otherwise allowable by law, whichever is greater. The current
franchise fee amount for the Municipality is 3.5% of the gross revenues
pursuant to N.J.S.A. 48:5A-30(d).
§ T5AA-6. Franchise territory. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 6]
The consent granted under this chapter for the renewal of the franchise
shall apply to the entirety of the Municipality and any property
subsequently annexed hereto.
§ T5AA-7. Extension of service. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 7]
The Company shall be required to proffer service to any residence along
any public right-of-way in the Primary Service Area, as set forth in the
Company's Application. Any extension of plant beyond the Primary Service
Area shall be governed by the Company's Line Extension Policy, as set
forth in the Company's Application, with a HPM ("homes-per-mile") of 25
dwellings per linear mile from the nearest active trunk or feeder line.
§ T5AA-8. Construction Requirements. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 8]
(a) Restoration: In the event that the Company or its agents shall disturb
any pavement, street surfaces, sidewalks, driveways, or other surface
in the natural topography, the Company shall, at its sole expense,
restore and replace such places or things so disturbed in as good a
condition as existed prior to the commencement of said work.
(b) Relocation: If at any time during the period of this consent, the
Municipality shall alter or change the grade of any street, alley or other
way or place the Company, upon reasonable notice by the Municipality,
shall remove, re-lay or relocate its equipment, at the expense of the
Company prior to approval of the board.
(c) Removal or trimming of trees: During the exercise of its rights and
privileges under this franchise, the Company shall have the authority to
trim trees upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks or other
public places of the Municipality so as to prevent the branches of such
trees from coming in contact with the wires and cable of the Company.
Such trimming shall be only to the extent necessary to maintain proper
clearance of the Company's wires and cables.
(d) Temporary removal of cables: The Company shall, upon request of the
Municipality, at the Company's expense, temporarily raise, lower or
remove its lines in order to facilitate the moving of buildings or
machinery or in other like circumstances, subject to the prior approval
of the Board.
(e) Installation of Equipment: The Company shall install equipment in the
same location and manner as existing public utilities whenever
§ T5AA-5 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T5AA-8
BAO:827
§ T5AA-9. Customer service. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 9]
In providing services to its customers, the Company shall comply with
N.J.A.C. § 14:18-1, et seq. and all applicable State and Federal statutes
and regulations. The Company shall strive to meet or exceed all voluntary
company and industry standards in the delivery of customer service and
shall be prepared to report on it to the Municipality upon written request of
the Municipality Administrator or Clerk.
§ T5AA-10. Municipal Complaint Officer. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 10]
The Office of Cable Television is hereby designated as the Complaint Officer
for the Municipality pursuant to N.J.S.A. § 48:5A-26(b). All complaints shall
be received and processed in accordance with N.J.A.C. § 14:17-6.5. The
Municipality shall have the right to request copies of records and reports
pertaining to complaints by Municipality customers from the OCTV.
§ T5AA-11. Local office. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 11]
During the term of this franchise, and any renewal thereof, the Company
shall maintain a business office or agent in accordance with N.J.A.C.
§ 14:18-5.1 for the purpose of receiving, investigating and resolving all local
complaints regarding the quality of service, equipment malfunctions, and
similar matters. Such a business office shall have a publicly listed toll-free
telephone number and be open during standard business hours.
§ T5AA-12. Performance bond. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 12]
During the life of the franchise the Company shall give to the Municipality
a bond in the amount of $25,000. Such bond shall be to insure the faithful
possible, in order to minimize the impact of same on surrounding
property.
(a) The Company shall continue to comply fully with all applicable State
and Federal statutes and regulations regarding credit for outages, the
reporting of same to regulatory agencies and notification of same to
customers.
(b) The Company shall continue to fully comply with all applicable State
and Federal statutes and regulations regarding the availability of
devices for the hearing impaired and the notification of same to
customers.
(c) The Company shall use every reasonable effort to meet or exceed
voluntary standards for telephone accessibility developed by the
National Cable Television Association ("NCTA").
(d) Nothing herein shall impair the right of any subscriber or the
Municipality to express any comment with respect to telephone
accessibility to the Complaint Officer, or impair the right of the
Complaint Officer to take any action that is permitted under law.
§ T5AA-8 PRINCETON CODE § T5AA-12
BAO:828
performance of all undertakings of the Company as represented in its
Application for Municipal Consent incorporated herein.
§ T5AA-13. Subscriber rates. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 13]
The rates of the Company shall be subject to regulation as permitted by
Federal and State law.
§ T5AA-14. Commitments by the Company. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 14;
Ord. No. 2018-20]
(a) The Company shall provide Expanded Basic or a similar tier of cable
television service to one outlet at no cost to each qualified existing and
future school in the Municipality, public and private, elementary,
intermediate and secondary, provided the school building is within 200
feet of active cable distribution plant or through customer owned
conduit. Each additional outlet installed, if any, shall be paid for on a
materials plus labor basis by the school requesting service.
(b) The Company shall provide Expanded Basic or a similar tier of cable
television service at no cost to one outlet to each qualified existing and
future municipal building, police, fire, emergency management facility
and public library in the Municipality, provided the facility is located
within 200 feet of active cable distribution plant or through customer
owned conduit. Each additional outlet installed, if any, shall be paid for
on a materials plus labor basis by the Municipality.
(c) Within six months of the issuance of a Renewal Certificate of Approval
by the BPU, the Company shall provide to the Municipality a one-time
Technology Grant in the amount of $75,000 to meet the technology and/
or cable related needs of the community.
(d) The Communications Act of 1934, as amended [47 U.S.C. § 543 (b)],
allows the Company to itemize and/or identify: (1.) the amount on the
subscriber bill assessed as a franchise fee and the identity of the
governmental authority to which the fee is paid; (2.) the amount on the
bill assessed to satisfy any requirements imposed on the Company by
the cable franchise to support public, education, and/or governmental
access channels, the use of such channels or required to meet the
technology and/or cable related needs of the community; and (3.) any
grants or other fees on the bill or any tax, assessment, or charge of any
kind imposed by any governmental authority on the transaction
between the operator and the subscriber. The Company reserves its
external cost, pass-through rights to the full extent permitted by law.
(e) The Company shall provide additional services as outlined in a separate
letter of agreement attached hereto as Exhibit A.23
23.Editor's Note: Exhibit A is included as an attachment to this Chapter.
§ T5AA-12 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T5AA-14
BAO:829
§ T5AA-15. Public, educational and governmental access. [Ord. No.
2016-35 § 15; Ord. No. 2018-20]
(f) The Company shall meet with the Council or their designee annually
upon written request of the Municipality.
(a) The Company will continue to provide one channel for public access and
one channel for governmental access. It will be on the most basic tier of
service offered by the Company in accordance with the Cable Act,
Section 611 [47 U.S.C. § 531], and as further set forth herein.
(b) The Company does not relinquish its ownership of or ultimate right of
control over a channel by designating it for PEG access use. A PEG
access user - whether an educational or government user - acquires no
property or other interest by virtue of the use of a channel so
designated, and may not rely on the continued use of a particular
channel number, no matter how long the same channel may have been
designated for such use.
(c) The Company shall not exercise editorial control over the use of any
educational or governmental channel capacity, except Company may
refuse to transmit any educational or governmental access program or
portion of any public or governmental access program that contains
obscenity, indecency, or nudity.
(d) Public access. "Public access" shall mean non-commercial use by the
public.
(e) Educational access. "Educational access" shall mean non-commercial
use by educational institutions such as public or private schools, but not
"home schools," community colleges and/or universities.
(f) Government access. "Government access" shall mean non-commercial
use by the governing bodies of the Municipality for the purpose of
showing the public local government at work.
(g) Fallow time. Because blank or underutilized PG channels are not in the
public interest, in the event the Municipality or other PG access users
elect not to fully program the PG access channel, the Company may
program unused time on those channels subject to reclamation by the
Municipality upon no less than 60 days' written notice.
(h) The Communications Act of 1934, as amended [47 U.S.C. § 543 (b)],
allows the Company to itemize and/or identify: (1.) the amount on the
subscriber bill assessed as a franchise fee and the identity of the
governmental authority to which the fee is paid; (2.) the amount on the
bill assessed to satisfy any requirements imposed on the Company by
the cable franchise to support public, education, and/or governmental
access channels, the use of such channels or required to meet the
technology and/or cable related needs of the community; and (3.) any
grants or other fees on the bill or any tax, assessment, or charge of any
kind imposed by any governmental authority on the transaction
§ T5AA-14 PRINCETON CODE § T5AA-15
BAO:830
§ T5AA-16. Emergency uses. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 16]
§ T5AA-17. Liability insurance. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 17]
The Company shall at all times maintain a commercial general liability
insurance policy with a single limit amount of $1,000,000 covering liability
for any death, personal injury, property damages or other liability arising
out of its construction and operation of the cable television system, and an
excess liability (or "umbrella") policy in the amount of $5,000,000.
§ T5AA-18. Incorporation of the Application. [Ord. No. 2016-35
§ 18]
All of the statements and commitments contained in the Application or
annexed thereto and incorporated therein, and any amendment thereto,
except as modified herein, are binding upon the Company as terms and
conditions of this consent. The Application and other relevant writings
submitted by the Company shall be annexed hereto and made a part hereof
by reference provided same do not conflict with application State or Federal
law.
§ T5AA-19. Competitive equity. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 19]
Should the Municipality grant Municipal Consent for a franchise to
construct, operate and maintain a cable television system to any other
person, corporation or entity on terms materially less burdensome or more
favorable than the terms contained herein, the Company may substitute
such language that is more favorable or less burdensome for the
comparable provision of this chapter subject to the provisions of N.J.A.C.
§ 14:17-6.7.
between the operator and the subscriber. The Company reserves its
external cost, pass-through rights to the full extent permitted by law.
(i) The Company shall provide additional services as outlined in a separate
letter of agreement attached hereto as Exhibit A.24
(j) The Company shall meet with the Council or their designee annually
upon written request of the Municipality.
(a) The Company will comply with the Emergency Alert System ("EAS")
rules in accordance with applicable State and Federal statutes and
regulations.
(b) The Company shall in no way be held liable for any injury suffered by
the Municipality or any other person, during an emergency, if for any
reason the Municipality is unable to make full use of the cable television
system as contemplated herein.

§ T5AA-15 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T5AA-20

§ T5AA-20. Separability. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 20]
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this
chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court or
Federal or State agency of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be
deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision, and its validity or
unconstitutionality shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of
the chapter.
§ T5AA-21. Third party beneficiaries. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 21]
Nothing in this franchise or in any prior agreement is or was intended to
confer third-party beneficiary status on any member of the public to enforce
the terms of such agreements or franchise.
§ T5AA-22. Effective date. [Ord. No. 2016-35 § 22]
This chapter shall take effect immediately upon issuance of a Renewal
Certificate of Approval from the BPU.
Chapter T5AAA
(RESERVED)
Chapter T5B
DISCRIMINATION
Editor's Note: See also Borough Code § 2-90c, Civil Rights Commission.
§ T5B-1. Purpose of chapter. [Ord. No. 686, § 1; Ord. No. 705, § 1;
Ord. No. 82-2, § 1; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1]
The governing body of the township finds and declares that practices of
discrimination with respect to real property because of age, race, creed,
color, national origin, ancestry, marital status, sex, affectional or sexual
orientation, familial status, liability for service with the Armed Forces of
the United States, nationality or handicap are matters of concern to the
government of the township and that such discrimination threatens not only
the rights and proper privileges of persons but menaces the institutions and
foundations of a free democratic society. It is the policy of the township that
all persons shall have the opportunity to obtain all the accommodations,
advantages, facilities and privileges of real property in the township without
such discrimination, subject only to conditions and limitations applicable
alike to all persons. In furtherance of that policy, this chapter shall be
deemed an exercise of the police power of the township for the protection
of the public health, safety and morals and for the promotion of the general
welfare.
§ T5AA-20 PRINCETON CODE § T5B-2
BAO:832
§ T5B-2. Definitions. [Ord. No. 686, § 2; Ord. No. 705, § 1; Ord. No.
94-5, § 1]
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
COMMISSION — The joint commission on civil rights created by the
borough and the township.
FAMILIAL STATUS — Being the natural parent of a child, the adoptive
parent of a child, the foster parent of a child, having a "parent and child
relationship" with a child as defined by state law, or having sole or joint
legal or physical custody, care, guardianship, or visitation with a child, or
any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of
any individual who has not attained the age of 18 years.
HANDICAP — Physical disability, infirmity, malformation or disfigurement
which is caused by bodily injury, birth defect or illness, including epilepsy,
and which shall include, but not be limited to, any degree of paralysis,
amputation, lack of physical coordination, blindness or visual impediment,
deafness or hearing impediment, muteness or speech impediment, or a
physical reliance on a service or guide dog, wheelchair, or other remedial
appliance or device, or any mental, psychological or developmental
disability resulting from any anatomical, psychological, physiological or
neurological conditions which prevents the normal exercise of any bodily
or mental functions or is demonstrable, medically or psychologically, by
accepted clinical or laboratory diagnostic techniques.
HOUSING — Shall not fail to meet the requirements for housing for older
persons by reason of: Persons residing in such housing as of March 12, 1989
not meeting the age requirements under this definition, provided that new
occupants of such housing meet the age requirements under this definition;
or unoccupied units, provided that such units are reserved for occupancy by
persons who meet the age requirements under this definition.
HOUSING FOR OLDER PERSONS — Housing which is:
PERSON — One or more individuals, partnerships, associations,
organizations, cooperatives, corporations, legal representatives, trustees,
trustees in bankruptcy, receivers, fiduciaries and other legal entities.
REAL PROPERTY — Real estate, lands, tenements and hereditaments,
corporeal and incorporeal, and leaseholds.
UNLAWFUL DISCRIMINATION — Only those unlawful practices and acts
specified in section 5B-3 of this chapter.
Provided under any state or federal program that the Attorney General
determines is specifically designed and operated to assist elderly
persons (as defined in the state or federal program); or
(a)
(b) Intended for and solely occupied by persons 62 years of age or older; or
Intended and operated for occupancy by at least one person 55 years of
age or older per unit.

§ T5B-3. Unlawful acts. [Ord. No. 686, § 3; Ord. No. 705, § 1; Ord.
No. 82-2, § 2; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1.]
It shall be an unlawful discrimination:
(a) For the owner, lessee, sublessee, assignee or managing agent of, or
other person having the right of ownership or possession of or the right
to sell, rent, lease, assign or sublease any real property or part or
portion thereof, or any agent or employee of any of these, real estate
broker or salesman, attorney, auctioneer or court-appointed fiduciary or
agent, or any agent or employee of any of these:
(1) To refuse to sell, rent, assign, lease or sublease or otherwise to
deny to or withhold from any person or group of persons any real
property or part or portion thereof because of the age, race, creed,
color, national origin, ancestry, marital status, sex, affectional or
sexual orientation, familial status, liability for service in the Armed
Forces of the United States, nationality or handicap of such person
or group of persons; or
(2) To refuse to sell, rent, assign, lease or sublease, or offer for sale,
rental, lease, assignment or sublease any real property or part or
portion thereof to any person or group of persons or to refuse to
negotiate for the sale, rental, assignment, lease or sublease of any
real property or part or portion thereof to any person or group of
persons because of the age, race, creed, color or national origin,
ancestry, marital status, sex, affectional or sexual orientation,
familial status, liability for service in the Armed Forces of the
United States, nationality or handicap of such person or group of
persons, or to represent that any real property or portion thereof is
not available for inspection, sale, rental, assignment, lease or
sublease when in fact it is so available, or otherwise to deny or
withhold any real property or any part or portion of facilities
thereof to or from any person or group of persons because of the
age, race, creed, color or national origin, ancestry, marital status,
sex, affectional or sexual orientation, familial status, liability for
service in the Armed Forces of the United States, nationality or
handicap of such person or group of persons; or
(3) To discriminate against any person or group of persons because of
the age, race, creed, color or national origin, ancestry, marital
status, sex, affectional or sexual orientation, familial status, liability
for service in the Armed Forces of the United States, nationality or
handicap of such person or group of persons in the terms,
conditions or privileges of the sale, rental or lease of any real
property or part or portion or in the furnishing of facilities or
services in connection therewith; or
(4) To print, circulate, issue, display, post or mail, or cause to be
printed, published, circulated, issued, displayed, posted or mailed,
any statement, advertisement, publication or sign, or to use any
§ T5B-3 PRINCETON CODE § T5B-3
BAO:834
form of application for the purchase, rental, lease, assignment or
sublease of any real property or part or portion thereof or to make
any record or inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase,
rental, lease, assignment or sublease of any real property or part
or portion thereof which expresses, directly or indirectly, any
limitation, specification or discrimination as to age, race, creed,
color, national origin, ancestry, marital status, sex, affectional or
sexual orientation, familial status, liability for service in the Armed
Forces of the United States, nationality or handicap or any intent
to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination; or
(5) For the purpose of inducing a transaction for the sale or rental of
real property from which transaction such person or any of its
members may benefit financially, to represent that a change has
occurred or will or may occur in the composition with respect to
age, race, creed, color or national origin, ancestry, marital status,
sex, affectional or sexual orientation, familial status, liability for
service in the Armed Forces of the United States, nationality or
handicap of the owners or occupants in the block, neighborhood or
area in which the real property is located, and to represent, directly
or indirectly, that this change will or may result in undesirable
consequences in the block, neighborhood or area in which the real
property is located, including, but not limited to, the lowering of
property values, an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or a
decline in the quality of schools or other facilities.
(b) For any person, bank, banking organization, mortgage company,
insurance company or other financial institution, lender or credit
institution to whom application is made for financial assistance for the
purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or
maintenance of any real property or part or portion thereof or any
agent or employee thereof:
(1) To discriminate against any person or group of persons because of
the age, race, creed, color, national origin, ancestry, marital status,
sex, affectional or sexual orientation, familial status, liability for
service in the Armed Forces of the United States, nationality or
handicap of such person or group of persons or of the prospective
occupants or tenants of such real property or part or portion
thereof, in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying or
renewing, or in the fixing of the rates, terms, conditions or
provisions of any such financial assistance or in the extension of
services in connection therewith; or
(2) To use any form of application for such financial assistance or to
make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such
financial assistance which expresses, directly or indirectly, any
limitation, specification or discrimination as to age, race, creed,
color, national origin, ancestry, marital status, sex, affectional or
sexual orientation, familial status, liability for service in the Armed
Forces of the United States, nationality or handicap or any intent to
§ T5B-3 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T5B-3
BAO:835
§ T5B-4. Application of chapter. [Ord. No. 686, § 4; Ord. No. 705,
§ 1; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1.]
make any such limitation, specification or discrimination, unless
otherwise required by law or regulation to retain or use such
information.
(c) For any person to take reprisals against any person because that person
has opposed any practices or acts forbidden under this chapter or
because that person has filed a complaint, testified or assisted in any
proceeding under this chapter, or to coerce, intimidate, threaten or
interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account
of that person having aided or encouraged any other person in the
exercise or enjoyment of, any right granted or protected by this chapter.
(d) For any person to aid, abet, incite, compel or coerce the doing of any of
the acts forbidden under this chapter, or to attempt or conspire to do
so.
(e) (1) It shall be an unlawful discrimination for the township or other
local, civil or political subdivision of the State of New Jersey, or an
officer, employee, or agent thereof, to exercise the power to
regulate land use or housing in a manner that discriminates on the
basis of age, race, creed, color or national origin, ancestry, marital
status, sex, affectional or sexual orientation, familial status, liability
for service in the Armed Forces of the United States, nationality or
handicap.
(2) Any person claiming to be aggrieved by an unlawful discrimination
under this subsection shall enforce this subsection by private right
of action in Superior Court. This shall not apply to discrimination in
housing owned or managed by the township or other local, civil or
political subdivision of the State of New Jersey.
(a) The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the rental: (1) of a
single apartment or flat in a two-family dwelling, the other occupancy of
which is occupied by the owner as a residence or the household of the
owner's family at the time of such rental; or (2) of a room or rooms to
another person or persons by the owner or occupant as a residence or
the household of the owner or occupant's family at the time of such
rental.
(b) Nothing herein contained shall be construed to bar any religious or
denominational institution or organization, or any organization
operated for charitable or educational purposes, which is operated,
supervised or controlled by or in connection with a religious
organization, in the sale, lease or rental of real property, from limiting
admission to or giving preference to persons of the same religion or
denomination or from making such selection as is calculated by such
organization to promote the religious principles for which it is
established or maintained.

§ T5B-5. Filing of complaints with civil rights commission. [Ord.

(c) Nothing herein contained shall be construed to bar any person from
refusing to sell, rent, lease, assign or sublease any room, apartment or
flat in a dwelling or residential facility that is planned exclusively for
and occupied exclusively by individuals of one sex to any individual of
the opposite sex on the basis of sex, nor shall anything herein be

(a) Any person claiming to be aggrieved by an unlawful discrimination, as
specified in this chapter, may file a complaint with the commission
setting forth the name and address of the person alleged to have
committed the unlawful discrimination complained of, the particulars of
such unlawful discrimination and such other information as may be
required by the commission. This procedure may be followed
notwithstanding that a complaint for the same unlawful discrimination
shall be pending in the municipal court hereunder.
(b) The commission shall thereupon cause prompt investigation to be made
in connection therewith, and if it shall determine after such
investigation that probable cause exists for crediting the allegations of
the complaint, it shall immediately endeavor to eliminate the unlawful
discrimination complained of by conference, conciliation and
persuasion.
(c) No determination of the commission shall be used in any action in the
municipal court of the township for violation of this chapter.
(d) No complaint shall be filed with the commission later than 30 days after
the date of the unlawful discrimination complained of therein, and the
commission shall complete its investigation and determination and its
procedures, if any, for elimination of the unlawful discrimination
complained of, within 60 days after the filing of the complaint.
(e) A township employee must exhaust his or her administrative remedies
as set forth in the township personnel manual before filing a complaint
with commission if the complaint relates to the employee's employment
with the township.

pending before the commission hereunder. However, no person shall be
prosecuted, tried or punished in the municipal court for any violation of this
chapter unless the complaint shall be filed in such court within 90 days after
the time of the violation complained of therein.
Chapter T6
(RESERVED)
Chapter T6A
EMPLOYEES — DEFENSE AND INDEMNIFICATION
§ T6A-1. Intent and purpose. [Ord. No. 934, § 1.]
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to provide for the defense of
actions against and the indemnification of public employees as permitted by
N.J.S.A. 59:10-1, et seq.
§ T6A-2. Definitions. [Ord. 934, § 1]
As used in this chapter:
EMPLOYEE — Any officer, employee or servant, whether or not
compensated or part-time, who is authorized to perform any act or service;
provided, however, that the term does not include an independent
contractor.
PUBLIC EMPLOYEE — Any employee or former employee of the township.
§ T6A-3. Defense of actions. [Ord. No. 934, § 1]
The township shall provide for the defense of any action brought against
a public employee on account of any act or commission in the scope of
his employment, and this obligation shall extend to any cross-actions,
counterclaims or cross-complaint against such employee.
§ T6A-4. Exceptions. [Ord. No. 934, § 1.]
The provisions of section 6A-3 shall not be applicable when the township
committee determines that:
(a) The act or omission was not within the scope of employment; or
(b) The act or failure to act was because of actual fraud, willful misconduct
or actual malice; or
(c) The defense of the action or proceeding would create a conflict of
interest between the township and the public employee; or
§ T5B-6 PRINCETON CODE § T6A-4
BAO:838
§ T6A-5. Methods of providing defense. [Ord. No. 934, § 1.]
The township may provide any defense required of it under this chapter
through an attorney from its own staff or by employing other counsel.
§ T6A-6. Township control over litigation. [Ord. No. 934, § 1.]
Whenever the township provides any defense required of it under this
chapter, the township, through counsel, may assume exclusive control over
the representation of the public employee, and such employee shall
cooperate fully with the defense.
§ T6A-7. Indemnification. [Ord. No. 934, § 1; Ord. No. 88-27, § 1.]
In any case where the township is required to provide a defense under this
chapter, the township shall pay or shall reimburse the public employee for:
Chapter T6B
(d) The defense of the action or proceeding is provided for by an insurance
policy or policies, whether obtained by the township or by any other
person; or
(e) The public employee failed to deliver to the township administrator,
within 10 calendar days after the time he is served with any summons,
complaint, process, notice, demand or pleading, the original or a copy
of the same; or
(f) The public employee has failed to cooperate fully with the defense.
(a) Any bona fide settlement agreements entered into by the employee; and
(b) Any judgments entered against the employee; and
(c) Any exemplary or punitive damages resulting from the employee's civil
violation of state or federal law if, in the opinion of the township
committee, the acts committed by the employee upon which damages
are based did not constitute actual fraud, actual malice, willful
misconduct or an intentional wrong; and
(d) If the township has failed to provide such required defense, all costs of
defending the action, including reasonable counsel fees and expenses,
together with costs of any appeal.
In addition, in any case where the township would be required to
provide a defense under this chapter except for the fact that such
defense is provided for by insurance, the township shall provide
indemnification as aforesaid, but only to the extent not covered by
insurance.
Nothing in this chapter shall authorize the township to pay for punitive
or exemplary damages or damages resulting from the commission of a
crime.

§ T6A-7 PRINCETON CODE § T6A-7
BAO:840
ARTICLE I
In General
§ T7-1. Payroll account authorized; method of payment of
compensation.25 [Ord. No. 264, § 1]
§ T7-2. Exemption of personal property from taxation.26 [Ord. No.
415, §§ 1, 2]
No tangible household personal property and personal effects located
within the township shall be assessed or taxed.
This section shall apply to taxes on tangible household personal property
and personal effects due and payable in the year 1962 and thereafter so
long as this section shall be in effect, and shall not affect the obligation,
lien or duty to pay any taxes, interest or penalties which have accrued or
(a) At the first meeting of the township committee in January of each year,
there shall be approved an account to be designated the township
payroll account. From time to time the township treasurer, upon receipt
of a warrant for the amount due the township payroll account, shall
deposit the warrant to the credit of the township payroll account and
charge the appropriate budgetary accounts therewith.
(b) The township treasurer shall thereafter draw checks on the township
payroll account to the employees entitled to payment therefrom.
(c) The township treasurer shall present monthly to the township
committee for approval warrants drawn to the order of the township
payroll account in advance for all employees whose salaries are on an
annual or hourly basis when such salaries are due and payable prior to
the next regular meeting of the township committee.
(d) At each regular meeting of the township committee, the township
treasurer shall submit for the approval or ratification, as the case may
be, the necessary payrolls for the amount due the several officers and
employees for compensation. The payroll shall be considered by the
township committee in due course and approved if found to be correct.
(e) In case of error or adjustment in the payroll, it shall be the duty of the
township treasurer to see that such error or adjustment is properly
corrected and appropriate record made thereof.
(f) Such officers as may be designated by the township committee are
authorized to sign warrants drawn in favor of the payroll account upon
due notice that the appropriate payrolls have been approved by the
proper committee and by the proper certifying authorities.

may accrue by virtue of any assessment made or which may be made with

§ T7-2 PRINCETON CODE § T7-2
BAO:842
ARTICLE II
Approval and Payment of Claims27
§ T7-3. Procedure in presentation of claims to township. [Ord. No.
503, § 1; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1]
Any person claiming payment from the township shall present a detailed bill
of demand to the township chief financial officer, duly certified or supported
by an affidavit of the claimant, as provided by section 40A:5-16 of the
Revised Statutes of New Jersey.
§ T7-4. Certification by department heads or employees. [Ord. No.
503, § 2; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1.]
It shall be the duty of the township chief financial officer to see that the
signature of the officer or employee, who has been duly designated by the
township committee to certify that the materials have been received by or
the services rendered to the township, appears on every claim, as provided
by section 40A:5-16 of the Revised Statutes of New Jersey.
§ T7-5. Approval of claims by department head and chief financial
officer; approved claims filed with township clerk for submission of
bill list to township committee. [Ord. No. 503, § 3; Ord. No. 92-10,
§ 1.]
After presentation to the township clerk, claims shall be presented to the
department head and chief financial officer responsible for the placing
of the order who, if satisfied that the claims are proper, shall approve
the claims. After such approval is given, the department head and chief
financial officer shall file the claims with the township clerk, who shall
then present the claims on a bill list to the township committee for formal
approval at a regular meeting.
§ T7-6. Approval or rejection of claims by township committee;
referral back to township clerk of rejected claims. [Ord. No. 503,
§ 4; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1.]
Claims as set forth on the bill list shall be considered by the township
committee which shall approve the same; except, that the township
committee may reject any claim presented to it, stating the reason for such
rejection. Any disapproved claim shall be referred back to the township
clerk with such instructions as the township committee may give at the time
of disapproval.
§ T7-7. Recording disposition of claims after township committee
action. [Ord. No. 503, § 5, Ord. No. 92-10 § 1.]
It shall be the duty of the township clerk to record all claims as set forth on
the bill list in the official minutes, indicating that the township committee
27.For state law as to when a township may pay out money, see R.S., § 40A:5-16
§ T7-3 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T7-7
BAO:843
has by formal action approved the same, with appropriate record as to any
claims disapproved or rejected.
§ T7-8. Indication of approval by designated chief financial officer.
[Ord. No. 503, § 6; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1.]
It shall be the duty of the chief financial officer to indicate on the claims
that they have been approved for payment, with the date of approval thereof
noted on the claim.
§ T7-9. Signing and recording checks in payment of claims;
distribution of checks to claimants. [Ord. No. 503, § 7; Ord. No. 724,
§ 1; Ord. No. 892, § 1; Ord. No. 92-10, § 1.]
After the chief financial officer has certified that the claims have been
approved, he shall forthwith prepare the necessary checks for the payment
of the claims. The checks shall be signed by the mayor, the township chief
financial officer, and the township clerk. After preparing the checks for the
payment of claims, the chief financial officer shall record them in proper
books of account and thereafter mail or otherwise distribute the checks to
the claimants.
§ T7-7 PRINCETON CODE § T7-9
BAO:844
ARTICLE III
Tax Sale Certificate Redemptions
§ T7-10. Tax sale certificate redemptions. [Ord. No. 2010-15, § 1.]
The tax collector shall provide to any party entitled to redeem a tax sale
certificate pursuant to N.J.S.A. 54:5-54 two calculations of the amount
required for redemption within a calendar year at no cost. The tax collector
shall charge a fee of $50 for each subsequent calculation requested within
a calendar year. A request for a redemption calculation shall be made in
writing to the tax collector.
The tax collector shall charge to a lien holder a fee of $50 for the calculation
of the amount due to redeem a tax lien. Any requests for a redemption
calculation shall specify the date to be used for the calculation, which shall
be the date of the notice. Neither the tax collector or the township shall be
liable for an incorrect calculation. The fee paid to the township by the lien
holder shall not become a part of the lien and shall not be passed on to any
party entitled to redeem the lien.
§ T7-10 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T7-10
BAO:845
Chapter T7A
FIRE INSURANCE CLAIMS PAYMENT
§ T7A-1. Payment prohibited until taxes, assessments, etc., are
paid. [Ord. No. 992, § 2.]
No insurance company authorized to issue fire insurance policies in the
State of New Jersey shall pay any claim in excess of $2,500, for fire damages
to real property located within the township, unless or until all taxes,
assessments and other municipal liens or charges due and payable
appearing on the official certificate of search shall have been paid either by
the owner of such real property or by the insurance company as provided in
section 3 of P.L. 1978, c. 184; or the municipality submits to the insurance
company a copy of a resolution adopted pursuant to section 4 of P.L. 1978
c.184.
§ T7A-2. Alteration of certificate of search. [Ord. No. 992, § 2.]
The official certificate of search may, from time to time, be altered, by
the bonded official responsible for preparing such certificates, in order to
cancel any error or omissions or to add any municipal liens or related
charges due and payable subsequent to the preparation of the official
certificate.
§ T7A-3. Appeal amount of lien or charge. [Ord. No. 992, § 3.]
In the event an appeal is taken on the amount of any lien or charge, other
than an appeal on the assessed valuation of real property pursuant to R.S.
54:3-21, the insurance company shall withhold 75% of the full amount of
lien or charge being contested pending termination of all proceedings, at
which time such moneys and all interest accruing thereon at a rate paid
on interest bearing accounts in banking institutions or savings and loan
associations in the State of New Jersey, shall be disbursed in accordance
with a final order or judgment of the court.
§ T7A-4. Priority of claims payment. [Ord. No. 992, § 4.]
Any claim on behalf of the township made in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter and P.L. 1978, c. 184 shall be paramount to any other claims
on the proceeds of the fire insurance policy, except the claim of a holder of
a mortgage on the fire damaged property, where the fire insurance policy
at the time of the loss listed the mortgagee as a named insured, in which
event the claim of the mortgagee to the proceeds shall be paramount to
the municipal lien only to the extent of the amount due and payable to the
mortgagee under the mortgage contract.
§ T7-10 PRINCETON CODE § T7A-5
BAO:846
§ T7A-5. Future property policies subject to chapter provisions.
[Ord. No. 992, § 5.]
All fire insurance policies covering property within the township, issued or
renewed after the adoption of this chapter and the filing of a copy of this
chapter with the State Commissioner of Insurance shall be subject to the
provisions of this chapter.
Chapter T8
PRINCETON FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ T7A-5 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T7A-5
BAO:847

ARTICLE I
Organization
§ T8-1. Definitions. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
As used in this chapter:
ASSOCIATE MEMBER — Means a member of the Princeton fire department
who is not a member of any of the three fire companies described in section
8-2 of this article.
AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE — Means those vehicles that are
defined and authorized as such under the laws of the State of New Jersey.
CHIEF OF POLICE — Means the chief of the police department of the
Municipality of Princeton, or designee.
DEPARTMENT — Means the Princeton fire department.
DIRECTOR OF EMERGENCY AND SAFETY SERVICES (ALSO REFERRED
TO HEREIN AS (DIRECTOR) — Means the Princeton department head
responsible for all fire prevention and safety matters in the municipality.
MEMBER OR REGULAR MEMBER — Means a member of the Princeton fire
department who is a member of one of the three fire companies described
in section 8-2 of this article.
PERSON — Means any individual, corporation, association, partnership,
other legal entity, government, or governmental subdivision or agency.
PRINCETON — Means the Municipality of Princeton, County of Mercer,
State of New Jersey.
PRINCETON FIRE DEPARTMENT (ALSO REFERRED TO HEREIN AS
DEPARTMENT OR PFD) — Means the fire department of the Municipality of
Princeton.
SOGS OR SOG — Means the Standard Operating Guidelines of the
department.
§ T8-2. Division into companies. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
(a) The Princeton fire department shall consist of three companies, known
as "Princeton Hook and Ladder Company," "Mercer Engine Co. No. 3"
and "Princeton Engine Co. No. 1," which shall be responsible for
providing fire protection to Princeton, subject to the general control
and management of Princeton. This chapter and the Princeton fire
department standard operating guidelines (SOGs) shall take
precedence over the individual company constitutions, bylaws and any
other rules or guidelines the individual companies may have in place.
(b) Each company of the department shall be entitled to receive a stipend
to be funded through the department budget, upon the approval of a
purchase order by the Princeton administrator.
§ T8-1 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-3
BAO:849
§ T8-3. Management of fire department. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
The general control and management of the department shall be the
responsibility of the Princeton mayor and council and the director of
emergency and safety services. The director may delegate this
responsibility to the chief, deputy chief and assistant chief, who may also
be referred to as DCs (department chiefs) in this chapter and other PFD
documents. The chief shall meet regularly with the director, fire officials,
and elected line officers of the department in accordance with the SOGs of
the department.
§ T8-3 PRINCETON CODE § T8-3
BAO:850
ARTICLE II
Membership Requirements; Membership Approvals
§ T8-4. Qualifications. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
No person shall become a member or associate member of the Princeton
fire department, unless said person shall meet the following qualifications:
§ T8-5. Oath. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
Before an applicant is accepted for regular or associate membership into
the department and enters upon the duties connected with said department,
said applicant shall take an oath to perform the duties of a member of
the Princeton fire department, to obey the officers of the Princeton fire
department and to comply in all respects with provisions of this chapter,
the Princeton Code and rules and regulations concerning the conduct of the
Princeton fire department. Each member shall sign an affidavit provided by
the Princeton clerk confirming receipt of a full copy of the fire department's
then current Standard Operating Guidelines.
§ T8-6. Training requirements. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
(a) Maintain a principal residence within a fifteen-mile radius of 363
Witherspoon Street. An individual who is available to respond to fires
during their regular work hours by virtue of employment within said
fifteen-mile radius shall be exempt from meeting this residency
requirement. Individuals who were members of the department as of
June 10, 1982, shall be recognized as members of said department as
defined herein and need not comply at any time with any residency
requirements provided for herein. For good cause shown, the mayor
and council may waive the residency requirement.
(b) Be at least 18 years of age.
(c) Be in good health, to be evidenced by a certificate to that effect by a
licensed physician of the State of New Jersey who has been chosen by
Princeton.
(d) Be eligible for and accepted for coverage under that certain group
accident insurance policy issued to the department through Princeton
and any renewal or replacement thereof.
(a) Upon entering the Princeton fire department each new regular and
associate member shall, within an eighteen-month period, complete
and pass a Firefighter I course or equivalent as well as any other New
Jersey State mandated courses. The director of emergency and safety
services with the concurrence of the chief may grant an extension of
this period only where completion of the course within this time period
is not possible due to changes in the schedule of course offering or
some other extenuating circumstance.
§ T8-4 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-6
BAO:851
§ T8-7. Approval of members of companies. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
§ T8-8. Status change. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
Any person who shall have served as a member of the department and
who has met the quota requirements of the New Jersey State Fireman's
(b) All members must pass the Firefighter I or a New Jersey State approved
program and any other mandated courses and training to remain a
firefighting member of the department; any member who does not
complete this training within the specified time shall become one of the
non-firefighting types of member listed in section 8-7(e).
(a) The various companies of the Princeton fire department shall process
their own members and associate members, but no person shall become
a member or associate member of the Princeton fire department until
approved by the Princeton mayor and council.
(b) Associate members approved by the mayor and council shall not be
members of a company of the Princeton fire department but shall be
subject to all provisions of this chapter. Associate members may at any
time apply to become a member of a company. If accepted into a
company, associate member status will no longer apply.
(c) Should an associate member wish to join the New Jersey State
Fireman's Association (NJSFA), the member will be required to join one
of the three fire companies and will lose associate status. Due to time
limits by the NJSFA on accepting medical doctors' physicals (12 months
from date of physical), associate members will be responsible for the
cost of a new physical if required by the NJSFA.
(d) Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, associate members shall
be entitled to the same benefits as regular members of the Princeton
fire department.
(e) Each company may at its own discretion have various types of
memberships. These memberships are not subject to the approval of
the mayor and council. Such memberships include but are not limited
to:
(1) Honorary members;
(2) Life members;
(3) Auxiliary members;
(4) Social or administrative members.
Only members who are active interior, exterior and junior
firefighters, apparatus drivers, fire police and command staff may
be present in any role at an incident requiring fire department
action as defined in SOGs.

Association may, upon application, be retired from active service upon the
vote of the company of which that person is a member.

ARTICLE III
Line Officers
§ T8-9. Election of captains of fire department; term; duties;
vacancies. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
§ T8-10. Election of lieutenants; term; duties; vacancies. [Ord. No.
2017-63]
(a) In September of an election year each company shall nominate
members for the maximum of two positions of captain of the fire
department members who meet all training requirements outlined for
that position in the SOGs. The nominees will be interviewed by the
chiefs and the director of emergency and safety services, designated as
the captains' interview committee. The names of the nominees selected
by the captains' interview committee will be put on a department ballot
and the department members will vote for the captain positions in
October of the election year. The two candidates receiving the top two
vote counts will be elected to the position of captain. The term of office
of a captain is two years.
(b) In the event of a vacancy in the office of a captain for a reason other
than expiration of a term, the captains' interview committee may
appoint a member meeting all qualifications to fill the vacancy until the
next election cycle; the committee retains the option to leave the
position vacant until the next election cycle.
(c) The captains shall be responsible for the proper care of the fire
apparatus and all like property pertaining thereto and belonging to
Princeton. The captains shall report any equipment defect or necessary
repairs in a timely manner to the fire chief or director of emergency and
safety services. The captains shall preserve order and discipline in the
department at all times; and when on duty at fires, they shall obey all
orders of the officer in command. In the absence of a captain, the next
in command of the department, shall direct all or any portion of
company drills or training sessions at least once in each month. In
addition, the captains shall perform all duties as outlined within the fire
department SOGs.
(a) In November of an election year, each company shall nominate for the
position of lieutenant for that company members who meet all training
requirements outlined for that position in Standard Operating
Guidelines. The nominees will be interviewed by the chiefs and
captains, designated as the lieutenants' interview committee. The
names of the nominees selected by the committee as eligible for
election shall be sent to their respective companies. Each company
shall then vote for one of the candidates from that company. The
candidates receiving the highest number of votes in each company will
be elected to the position of lieutenant for that company. The election
§ T8-9 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-10
BAO:855
§ T8-11. Further duties of captains and lieutenants. [Ord. No.
2017-63]
Line officers, when on duty at fires, or on any occasion where the
department is engaged, shall obey the directions of the fire chief, whose
judgment and authority shall be deemed paramount and conclusive. They
shall, under said direction, take proper measures to arrange the apparatus
and to manage the personnel of the department in the most advantageous
manner for the effective extinguishing of fires.
for lieutenant will be held in December of the election year. The term of
office for a lieutenant is two years.
(b) In the event of a vacancy in the office of a lieutenant for a reason other
than expiration of a term, the lieutenants' interview committee may
appoint a member meeting all qualifications to fill the vacancy until the
next election cycle; the committee retains the option to leave the
position vacant until the next election cycle.
(c) If a company does not have any eligible member to nominate for the
position of lieutenant, the company shall nominate one or more
candidates from the remaining pool of members, subject to interview
and approval by the lieutenants' interview committee and subsequent
vote by the members for the remaining position at a special company
meeting. The person receiving the highest vote count will hold the
position of lieutenant.
(d) The lieutenants shall perform all duties as outlined within the fire
department SOGs.
§ T8-10 PRINCETON CODE § T8-11
BAO:856
ARTICLE IV
Discipline of Officers and Members
§ T8-12. Failure to follow orders. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
Any officer or member of the department, while on duty, who shall refuse
or negligently fail to obey or execute any order from the officer(s) in charge
of any fire, emergency or nonemergency activity in which the Princeton fire
department has been called, shall, for such offense, be subject to discipline
from a warning to a suspension or termination from the department in such
manner and upon such hearing as may be prescribed by the SOGs of the
Princeton fire department. A terminated or suspended officer or member
shall be entitled to an appeal hearing in accordance with the procedures set
forth in section 8-14.
§ T8-13. Other offenses or causes. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
For other offenses or causes, an officer or member of the department may
be subject to discipline from a warning to a suspension or termination
from the department in such manner and upon such hearing as may be
prescribed by the SOGs of the Princeton fire department. A terminated
or suspended officer or member shall be entitled to an appeal hearing in
accordance with the procedures set forth in section 8-14.
§ T8-14. Appeals. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
An officer or member who is terminated or suspended may appeal the
termination or suspension by requesting a hearing before an appeals
committee. The appeals committee shall consist of the director, the
company presidents and the chiefs. If a company president is not available,
that company's vice president shall serve on the committee. If a chief is
not available, a captain shall serve in lieu of that chief. Any appeal should
be made in writing and submitted to the director or to the municipal clerk
no more than 14 business days after the effective date of the suspension
or termination. The hearing shall be informal and shall take place no more
than 30 days after the filing of the appeal. All members of the appeals
committee shall participate in the appeal hearing. The appeals committee
may affirm, reverse or modify the decision appealed from; that decision
shall be final.
§ T8-12 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-14
BAO:857

ARTICLE V
Appointment of Fire Chiefs; Duties
§ T8-15. Positions; terms. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
§ T8-16. Princeton fire department chief appointment committee as
appointing authority; committee members. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
(a) Upon a vacancy occurring by reason of the expiration of a term, a fire
department chief, deputy fire chief or assistant fire chief shall be
appointed as set forth in this article. They shall hold their offices for a
maximum of three consecutive two-year terms. The only exception
would be in the event that no qualified members are available to fill the
position.
(b) All members shall be notified by the director of emergency and safety
services no less than 30 days prior to the commencement of the election
and appointment procedures set forth in this article.
(a) The Princeton fire department chief, deputy chief and assistant chief
shall be appointed by the Princeton fire department chief appointment
committee (hereinafter "chief appointment committee" or "committee")
which shall consist of the director, the Princeton administrator and
three past company chiefs of the Princeton fire department (one from
each company), as elected by each company.
(b) Each company shall hold an annual election in October to elect one past
company chief to serve on the Princeton fire department chief
appointment committee. Any current member who is a past company
chief who is interested in serving on the committee shall notify the
company president of that interest prior to the October company
meeting. If their qualifications for the committee are verified in
accordance with current company rules and procedures their names
shall be placed on the company ballot for the committee membership
election in October. No later than three days after each company
election, the names of the members elected to serve on the chief
appointment committee shall be provided to the director.
(c) In the event no current member who is a past chief is available or
willing to serve on the chief appointment committee, the president of a
company may appoint another member to serve on the chief
appointment committee. Any such appointee shall be qualified in
accordance with current department rules and procedures. The name
of such appointee shall be provided to the director along with the
names of elected members in accordance with subsection (b) of this
section.
(d) Company elections shall be conducted in accordance with current
company rules and procedures.
§ T8-15 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-17
BAO:859
§ T8-17. Eligibility for chief positions; applications; committee
procedures; appointment. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
(a) Any eligible member who is not a member of the chief appointment
committee may apply for a chief position. To be eligible for the position
of fire chief, deputy fire chief or assistant fire chief, each candidate
must provide proof of compliance with all training requirements
mandated by the fire department's rules and regulations. No candidate
may be a chief officer of another emergency services organization. All
candidates shall clearly specify the position sought and shall provide
copies of their training certificates to the director, or if designated by
the director, to the Princeton clerk, starting the first Monday in October
and no later than 5:00 p.m. on the first Monday in November.
(b) The director will certify those candidates meeting the requirements in
subsection (a) above and will provide a list of all qualified candidates to
the chief appointment committee. The qualified candidates will be
interviewed by the committee, and will be notified promptly by the
director of the time, place and procedures of the interview process. If
there is no qualified candidate for one or more of the chief positions, the
committee will proceed with the qualified candidate(s).
(c) Each candidate will be interviewed by the committee to assess each
candidate's firefighting experience, knowledge, and leadership
qualities; and to assess each candidate's views on what direction the
department should follow and what improvements and/or changes
should be made. The following are selection guidelines for the
committee to follow while evaluating the candidates:
(1) Technical skills as they relate to planning, organizing and
implementing fire suppression, training and technical rescue.
(2) Supervisory skills, ability to motivate the volunteer personnel.
Establish and maintain an effective working relationship with
members, administration, mutual aid departments and the
community.
(3) Ability to maintain departmental discipline and conduct and the
general behavior of the assigned personnel.
(4) Ability to develop and implement department standard guidelines
and operating procedures.
(5) Ability to work with the director and the Princeton administration
to develop budget plans as well as goals and long range planning
regarding the direction of the department.
(6) Ability to operate as the incident commander at an emergency
scene, including but not limited to fires, special details and rescue
operations.
§ T8-17 PRINCETON CODE § T8-17
BAO:860
§ T8-18. Confidentiality. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
§ T8-19. Compensation. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
The fire chief, deputy chief and assistant chief shall receive a stipend as
provided in the annual fire department budget.
§ T8-20. Fire chief authority; chain of command. [Ord. No. 2017-63]
(7) Ability to communicate both orally and in writing, understand
computer operations and the various computer programs used by
Princeton.
(d) After the interviews are completed, the committee by majority vote and
secret ballot will appoint a new chief, deputy chief, and assistant chief,
as applicable. The appointment procedures shall be completed by
December 15 and shall be announced and posted immediately after the
votes are counted. The decision of the chief appointment committee
shall be final. The director, on behalf of the committee, shall promptly
provide to the Princeton clerk a list of the appointments, so that the
names of the appointees may appear on the agenda for swearing in at
the reorganization meeting of the Princeton council the following year.
(a) All meetings and deliberations of the chief appointment committee shall
be confidential and closed.
(b) The time frames and deadlines required in this article shall be strictly
enforced.
(a) Fire chief authority at fire emergencies. The fire chief shall be the
ranking officer in the fire department. The fire chief shall, in all cases
where fire threatens life or damage or destruction of property within
Princeton, take prompt and efficient measures and use the means of the
department to extinguish the fire, and shall at such times and occasions
have the sole and absolute control and command over all the fire
apparatus and all members of the department at such fire.
(b) Fire chief general operational authority. The fire chief shall consult and
cooperate with the Princeton administrator and director of emergency
and safety services and shall be responsible to the director of
emergency and safety services and through the director to the
administrator and mayor and council of Princeton, for the conduct,
efficiency and management of the department and for the enforcement
of the rules and regulations governing the same, and for the carrying
out of lawful orders and instructions of the director, mayor and council
of Princeton and of the administrator.
(c) Chain of command. All orders and instructions to members of the fire
department shall be made by or through the fire chief or by or through
the officer in command in case of inability to communicate with the fire
chief. In the absence of the fire chief at any emergency or non-
§ T8-17 BOROUGH ADOPTING ORDINANCE § T8-20

§ T8-22. Officers' radio designations. [Ord. No. 2017-63]

emergency activity in which the fire department is operating, the chain
of command shall move to the next ranking officer, i.e., deputy chief,
then assistant chief, then to the ranks of captain and lieutenant, then
to drivers and firefighters. The SOGs contain further detail on chain of
command and incident command procedures.
(a) The chief in conjunction with the director of emergency and safety
services shall conduct inspections as appropriate and shall provide an
annual report on the general status of the department, fires attended,
manpower, apparatus, other equipment, and buildings and submit it to
the administrator.
(b) Public inspections. The fire chief will set the date and time for public
inspections of the department by the mayor and council. The chief shall
make all necessary rules and regulations governing public inspections.
